question: How does neural networking work and what are the uses of such systems ? I.E. Google 's Deep Dream project Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: A neural network is a mathematical model of brain cells ( neurons ) that are connected together . When one neuron is activated it sends a signal to other nearby neurons . When the signal reaches a certain treshold , it will fire a signal to the next neurons down the stream . " Neurons that fire together wire together " . This can be described mathematically by adding weights to different variables , for example neuron 1 ( n1 ) = 0.5 , n2 = 1 and n3 = 0 . When the treshold 0.5 is reached the neurons will fire . In this example , if all the neurons n1 - 3 recieve an input signal , n1 and n2 will fire , but not n3 because n3 is below the treshold . Now , because n1 fired together with n2 , the probability that the neuron will fire goes up , say : n1 = 0.75 . Common applications include face recognition , where neural networks can be trained to recognize faces based on facial features . The network scans images and based on its previous training , when the network was established when " viewing " faces , the network is able to recognize new faces , because the pattern of the firing is similar .

A Neural Networks ( NN for short ) is an idea that attempts to mimic the action of neurons ( those cells in your brain ) . Neurons receive signals from other neighboring neurons and other sources , and based on the signals they receive , they either themselves release a signal or do n't . A NN will do basically the same thing . You will have artificial neurons that receive some type of input ( from other neurons or directly from another input source ) , and based on the values of the inputs they receive , they " fire " some type of output . These outputs are then aggregated in some fashion to produce an output for the NN . The wiki page [ here ] ( URL_0 ) does a good job covering it in a bit more detail !

So this is n't going to be ELI5 , but it should be fine for high school students . While neural networks are modeled after our understanding of the human brain , even the most complicated ones are very simple compared to the brain . The primary use of neural networks is to be able to take as input some data that we know about an observation , such as the pixels in an image , and assign a label or classification to the observation , such as " cat " or " not a human face " . On the scale of networks that we use , it can be more useful to think of the networks in terms of what kinds of data it can discriminate . First , as robustoutlier mentioned , each neuron simply multiplies each input by a weight ( these weights are what is " trained " in a network ) , and then sums these values . The neuron 's output is then a function of this sum . Perhaps getting a little complicated here , but it is important that this function is non - linear , otherwise the entire network could be replaced with a single linear transformation ( also known as multiplying the input vector by a matrix ) and will have limited usefulness . As an example of what can be discriminated , imagine you have a graph line , with points on it . you have a point at ( 0 ) , which should be labeled " cat " , and one at ( 1 ) , which should be labeled " dog " . This is very easy to classify . A single neuron could could take as input the x coordinate , 0 for cat and 1 for dog , and have a threshold of 0.5 . Now , say you have some data that can not be approximated with one neuron : ( 0)-cat , ( 1)-dog , ( 2)-cat . A network like this ( very simplified , neurons in parentheses , the one to the right takes the two to left as input ) could solve that : x - ( x > 0.5 ? ) - * 0.5 - > (= 1 ? ) - > " dog " x - ( x < 1.5 ? ) - * 0.5 - > In essence , the first two do some of the work ( ruling out one of the cat points ) , and then the final one combines that work . Each layer of a network distorts the input data in such a way that the next layer has an easier task of classifying it . This is a really interesting blog post , even if you do n't understand it , I think it has some great visualizations . URL_0 There are some other really interesting things to keep in mind . First , it 's been shown that a network with a single hidden layer can approximate any function . ( this is somewhat simplified , URL_2 ) . So you may wonder why they make bigger networks . The answer to that is typically training limitations . It can be very slow to train such networks , and you may also have incomplete data to learn from ( i.e. , not every possible cat location is marked on the graph ) . " Deeper " networks with more hidden layers can help with this . You may also hear of recurrent networks ( RNN ) . These allow outputs of one layer to feed back into neurons on the same layer or before . This allows the network to have a " memory " . Some tasks , such as recognizing human speech , require the network to keep track of what it saw before , and so this is a way to do that . Another is convolutional network ( CNN ) , this is where small networks are trained for a given task , say detecting an edge in an image , and then many of them are used on small sections of the input image . This has the advantage of not having to train for the full problem size . Training an edge detector for inputs of say 100 pixels is much easier than for inputs of the whole image . The outputs of all of these small edge detectors ( or whatever task they do ) are then fed into another network where this information can be used . Finally , this site is great for experimenting and seeing what sorts of weird data you can classify using different network designs . URL_1

**What is Neural Networking?**

Think of a neural network like a brain made out of tiny computers (neurons). These tiny computers work together to learn things from examples. Just like how you learn by seeing lots of cats and dogs and then being able to tell them apart, a neural network learns by looking at many examples of something.

For example, if you show a neural network 100 pictures of cats and 100 pictures of dogs, it starts to learn what makes a cat different from a dog. It‚Äôs like your brain learning to recognize faces ‚Äî you see many faces and start to know what they look like.

**How Does It Work?**

- **Input Layer:** This is where information goes in, like a picture.
- **Hidden Layers:** These are like the thinking part. Each layer looks for patterns in the data. The first layer might look for edges, the next might find shapes, and so on until it recognizes something like a face or a word.
- **Output Layer:** This is where the answer comes out, like "This is a cat" or "This is a dog."

It's kind of like a puzzle that gets harder as you go deeper. Each layer helps solve a little piece of the bigger puzzle.

**What Are Some Uses?**

Neural networks are used in all sorts of cool ways:

- **Smart Phones:** They help your phone recognize your voice or take better photos.
- **Games:** They make games smarter, like helping characters learn from you.

Here's how it works in super simple terms:

1.  **The Pretend Brain:** We build something called an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) on a computer. It looks like lots and lots (and lots!) of layers of connected little dots.
2.  **Learning from Pictures:** We show this pretend brain thousands or millions of pictures with labels attached ("cat," "dog," "tree"). The more we show it, the better it learns which patterns belong to each thing.
3.  **Connecting the Dots:** As the pretend brain sees these pictures again and again, it makes up rules for itself about *how* different parts connect together to make shapes or objects. This is like memorizing examples until it knows the general idea.
4.  **Making Decisions:** After learning, if you give it a new picture without a label, it will try to figure out what's in it by following all its learned rules. Think: "Hmm, this shape has X and Y... Looks kinda like Z!"

question: Why is perpetual motion impossible ? I 'm an engineer and I understand why . But about once a month somebody comes to me with a new idea for a perpetual motion machine and they never seem to understand when I explain why it wo n't work . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Basically , it 's impossible for anything to be 100 % efficient , so it will always lose energy to that inefficiency . Any sort of friction , heat , etc in the tiniest amount is a loss of efficiency , and thus a loss of energy .

Law of conservation of energy . In order for a machine to be in perpetual motion , it has to maintain the same amount of energy , but it will inevitably lose some due to friction and imperfections in energy transfer . With something strictly mechanical it 's pretty easy to grasp , but I saw someone post on here an idea to use water pumps to power a hydroelectric generator , which would power the pumps . Unless you have a fairly good knowledge of the efficiency of pumps and hydroelectric generators it 's hard to work out exactly how much energy it would require , but a simple " law of conservation of energy , the pumps would require more power than the system would produce " explanation would be the best one in my opinion .

Perpetual motion requires no friction and no loss of energy . A system can only be called " perpetual " if it works forever * * without adding more energy to the system * * . That 's the reason it ca n't exist . We can not create a system that does not lose energy . If you have to add more , then the device can not work forever .
chatgpt_answers: Perpetual motion is impossible because it would violate the first and second laws of thermodynamics. The first law of thermodynamics is the law of energy conservation, which states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted from one form to another. The second law of thermodynamics is the law of entropy, which states that in any energy transfer or transformation, the total entropy (or disorder) of a closed system will always increase over time. In other words, perpetual motion machines are impossible because they would require a source of energy that never runs out, which goes against the first law of thermodynamics. They would also have to be able to convert that energy into useful work without increasing the total entropy of the system, which goes against the second law of thermodynamics. So, in short, perpetual motion is impossible because it would require breaking the fundamental laws of nature that govern how energy works.

Imagine you have a toy car that goes around and around on a track forever, without ever stopping ‚Äî even though no one is pushing it or giving it any energy.

Now, here‚Äôs the thing: **everything in the world slows down over time**. Even if you push the toy car really hard, it will eventually stop because of things like friction (the resistance between the wheels and the ground), air pushing against it, and gravity pulling it down. These are all invisible forces that take away energy from the toy car, just like how your legs get tired after running around.

So, a **perpetual motion machine** would need to run forever ‚Äî forever! That means **it can‚Äôt lose any energy at all**, not even a tiny bit. But we know that in real life, everything loses some energy over time. There‚Äôs always something slowing it down, taking away its power, or making it hotter, louder, or slower.

Think of it like trying to keep spinning a bicycle wheel forever. If you stop pedaling, the wheel will gradually slow down and stop. You‚Äôd have to keep adding more energy to make it go again. And there‚Äôs no way to do that without using up another source of energy ‚Äî like batteries, electricity, or even your own strength.

So, even though people come up with all kinds of clever ideas, they‚Äôre missing one very important rule:  
**Energy can‚Äôt be created out of nowhere**, and **nothing can run forever without losing energy**.

In short:  
*You can‚Äôt make something move forever without putting energy into it, and you can‚Äôt get energy out of nothing.*

It‚Äôs like trying to play a video game

question: Please explain what is "Quantum physics"
human_answers:
Quantum mechanics is a fundamental theory in physics that provides a description of the physical properties of nature at the scale of atoms and subatomic particles.:‚Ää1.1‚Ää It is the foundation of all quantum physics including quantum chemistry, quantum field theory, quantum technology, and quantum information science.
Classical physics, the collection of theories that existed before the advent of quantum mechanics, describes many aspects of nature at an ordinary (macroscopic) scale, but is not sufficient for describing them at small (atomic and subatomic) scales. Most theories in classical physics can be derived from quantum mechanics as an approximation valid at large (macroscopic) scale.
Quantum mechanics differs from classical physics in that energy, momentum, angular momentum, and other quantities of a bound system are restricted to discrete values (quantization); objects have characteristics of both particles and waves (wave‚Äìparticle duality); and there are limits to how accurately the value of a physical quantity can be predicted prior to its measurement, given a complete set of initial conditions (the uncertainty principle).
Quantum mechanics arose gradually from theories to explain observations which could not be reconciled with classical physics, such as Max Planck's solution in 1900 to the black-body radiation problem, and the correspondence between energy and frequency in Albert Einstein's 1905 paper which explained the photoelectric effect. These early attempts to understand microscopic phenomena, now known as the "old quantum theory", led to the full development of quantum mechanics in the mid-1920s by Niels Bohr, Erwin Schr√∂dinger, Werner Heisenberg, Max Born, Paul Dirac and others. The modern theory is formulated in various specially developed mathematical formalisms. In one of them, a mathematical entity called the wave function provides information, in the form of probability amplitudes, about what measurements of a particle's energy, momentum, and other physical properties may yield.
chatgpt_answers:
Quantum physics is a branch of physics that deals with the behavior of matter and energy at the atomic and subatomic level. It is based on the principles of quantum mechanics, which were developed in the early 20th century to explain the behavior of atoms and molecules.



In quantum physics, the basic units of matter and energy are called quantum particles, which can be particles like electrons and photons, or waves like sound and light. These quantum particles do not behave like classical particles, which we are used to seeing in our everyday lives. Instead, they exhibit properties that are fundamentally different and often counterintuitive.



One of the most famous examples of this is the uncertainty principle, which states that it is impossible to know both the exact position and the exact momentum of a quantum particle at the same time. This means that, on a quantum level, the world is fundamentally unpredictable and probabilistic.



Quantum physics has had a huge impact on our understanding of the universe and has led to many important technological developments, such as transistors, lasers, and computer memory. It is also a key component of modern chemistry, since it helps to explain the behavior of atoms and molecules.

question: Why do I see tiny white spots darting around my vision every time I look at the sky ? I do n't understand eyes . At all . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: First : URL_0 Finally : URL_1 Blue Field Entoptic Phenomenon . When I first noticed it I thought something of The Matrix .

As has been said , probably seeing the white blood vessels in your eyes . If you want to " see " the actual blood vessels in your eyes in your vision get a piece of card , prick a hole in it , not too small , not too big . Look at a bright , white surface , just go into MS Paint should be enough , put the card up to an eye , shut the other , and shake the card from side to side , up and down , whatever . Just a little bit but very rapid . You should see a spider web of black across your vision . That 's the shadows of the blood vessels , but your brain normally ignores them . If you do n't have a card to do it with you can use your hand . When you were a kid you probably pretended that your hand was a telescope when you were playing as a pirate or something . Do that but with your forefinger and thumb make a really tiny " telescope " .

The spots are actually from the intense blue in the sky . Wikipedia explains this blue field entoptic phenomenon as " white blood cells moving in the capillaries in front of the retina of the eye . Blue light is absorbed by the red blood cells that fill the capillaries . The eye and brain " edit out " the shadow lines of the capillaries , partially by dark adaptation of the photoreceptors lying beneath the capillaries . The white blood cells , which are much rarer than the red ones and do not absorb blue light , create gaps in the blood column , and these gaps appear as bright dots . "

These tiny white spots that you see darting around your vision are called "floaters." Floaters are small, cloudy or semi-transparent specks that move around in your field of vision. They are usually caused by small bits of debris that are floating in the fluid that fills the inside of your eye (called the vitreous).

When you look at the sky, you are looking at a very large and uniform surface. This can make floaters more noticeable because there is nothing else in your field of vision to distract your attention.

Floaters are common and usually not a cause for concern. However, if you suddenly see a lot of new floaters, or if you see flashes of light along with floaters, you should contact your eye doctor as these can be signs of a more serious problem with the retina (the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye).

question: Ron paul and his stance . I m just getting into the political world and seeing a bunch of hibidy jibidy from most if not all politicians . But Ron Paul at least seems to be consistent . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Ron Paul 's political stances come from the fundamental idea that the federal government should be limited by the constitution , and any powers not explicitly granted to the federal government should be left up to the individual states . He varies slightly on some of his stances ( IMO when his religious upbringing conflicts with this fundamental political stance ) , but generally he sticks to that principal . Supporters of Ron Paul like the idea of power moving towards a more local government , and the reduction in federal spending that would be required . Opponents of Ron Paul think his ideas are at best a pipe dream and at worst an attempt to retard / reverse current civil rights and environmental laws . In my personal opinion , Ron Paul is an empty vessel ; he wants to make a lot of changes , but the effects of his changes are largely unknown . People who want to see his changes enacted think the results will be good and people who do not want to see his changes enacted think the results will be bad . Supporters of Ron Paul probably think the individual states will generally do a good job of governing themselves or think that it 's just * right * that states should largely govern themselves . Opponents of Ron Paul think states will generally do a bad job of governing themselves or that the issues that will be left to the individual states are far too important to have ( possibly ) 50 different levels of protection .

- He 's a libertarian . He believes in individual freedom . Freedom to choose your education , your insurances or lack thereof , freedom to use drugs , etc . - He champions the constitution . He thinks the federal government is secondary to the state governments , and that the constitution is there to limit what the federal government can do . He thinks that the federal government is n't allowed to do what is n't specifically allowed by the constitution . - He 's against income taxes . And he thinks the government does n't need all that money . He thinks the government is wasting money , notably through wars . He would also replace some government projects by voluntary civilian projects , which is consistent with his libertarian position - He 's for a more isolationist USA , against interventionism , especially through wars . That 's his main policies , from the top of my head . A political quality he has is that he 's consistent in his positions . He does n't make compromises to become more electable . His positions reflect what he thinks , not what he feels people want to hear . He looks like one of the most honest candidates out there . His political downside is that some of his positions are not so pretty . He does n't believe in evolution . He thinks religion should play a bigger role in the country . He 's been associated with racists , but he claims that 's a wrongful association .

The best republican currently , but still a republican . He has some good ideas : stopping the wars in the middle east , legalizing all drugs , repealing Patriot act , and other personal liberty ideas . he also has some terrible ones : removing the department of education , epa , he said he would nt have voted for the civil rights act , and he is a christian fundamentalist . Common words that were used by the lower classes were German , whereas fancier , more academic terms were based more on a mix of French and Latin . An example of this split is the word for poop . " Shit " is German in origin , whereas " defecation " is derived from Latin . Source : A previous [ thread ] ( URL_0 ) on this topic .

question: Cortisone Injections Kindly explain to me what they do and how they help things such as muscle / cartilage tears ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: So first , a lot of the things cortisone is used to treat are inflammatory pains . Inflammation is caused by your immune system trying to protect and heal what ails you . Cortisone is a steroid that suppresses this response , reducing the pain .

Cortisone injections can work like magic . 24hrs after the first one for Achilles tendon problems I had to keep reminding myself that I did not need to limp anymore . The big downside is that it weakens the tendon and increases the risk of rupture and more serious problems later .

Cortisone is a steroid which is an anti inflammatory drug . Inflammation is a good thing in moderation but our bodies are not the best at controlling it . We therefore use the cortisone to reduce inflammation thereby reducing swelling , pain , and giving your knee more manoeuvrability .
chatgpt_answers:
Cortisone injections are a type of medication that is used to reduce inflammation and pain in a specific area of the body. When a person has an injury, such as a muscle or cartilage tear, the body's natural response is to send inflammation to the area to help it heal. This inflammation can cause swelling, redness, and pain. Cortisone injections can help reduce these symptoms by decreasing the amount of inflammation in the area.

To give a cortisone injection, a healthcare provider will numb the area with a local anesthetic and then use a very thin needle to inject the medication into the injured area. The cortisone works by blocking certain chemicals in the body that cause inflammation. This can help reduce swelling, redness, and pain, and can also help the injury heal faster.

Cortisone injections are usually only used for a short period of time, and are not intended to be a long-term solution for managing pain or inflammation. They can be helpful for people who are experiencing severe pain or inflammation that is not responding to other types of treatment. However, cortisone injections are not suitable for everyone, and a healthcare provider will carefully consider whether they are appropriate for a particular patient based on their individual circumstances.

Sometimes, when you fall or play too hard, you might hurt yourself ‚Äî like if you twist an ankle or maybe even tear a little piece of your leg (like a muscle or the soft stuff in your knee). That can make your joint very sore, swelled up, and itchy.

So, in simple words: **Cortisone injections are like giving your hurt part a cool, calming hug to make it feel better until it can heal properly.**

ortisone is a glucocorticoid steroid hormone that has anti-inflammatory actions. It is usually injected into a joint, tendon or bursa to relieve pain and inflammation. When cortisone is given by injection it quickly accumulates in the synovial fluid (the jelly-like lubricating substance around joints) where its effects are most potent.
Cortisone injections can provide quick relief for acute joint injuries, and are sometimes used before starting physical therapy to allow for improved movement without pain.
In general, when it comes to treating musculoskeletal injuries such as those affecting muscles and connective tissues like tendons and cartilages, there are two main types of treatments: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and corticosteroids. Corticosteroids work by reducing swelling and inflammation which can cause painful conditions such as bursitis or tendinitis.
They also have an analgesic effect because they block certain nerve fibers from sending signals that tell us we feel pain in the first place!

question: The difference between Marxism / Fascism / Communism I think I understand , but I 'm not sure . Any help would be great :) Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: The long version , someone else can provide the short . I interject a lot of history into this explanation which severely lengthens it , though I do n't think you can understand these concepts without learning about how they were applied . I did not discuss fascism here but will add it on to the end . The Communist Manifesto makes excellent critiques of capitalism . If you read it today , which i did last week , you 'll be amazed at how much of what he said applies to us now . The main problem is that Marx does n't give very clear answers for addressing the faults . His basic plan was that industrialized nations should move to socialism , and then after a period of adjustment move into communism . I 'll explain later why no communist country actually followed his plan . One of Marx and Engels arguments was that prior to industrialization , we produced not much more than we used . Obviously there was trade but for the most part the lack of machinery kept production levels low . Then machines come along and our ability to produce greatly increased . Adam Smith , the author of Wealth of Nations showed how division of labour increased production for manufacturers . Now instead of one person making a product , you might have 10 who accomplish different portions of the task . This made production go way up . What Marx criticized was the effect of having such a surplus . When you overproduce the price of the good decreases because the supply is so high . This required two things , one to reduce the cost of manufacturing to keep up with competition who , through free market competition , lower prices . The second was that you had to find new markets . Given the world at the time of Smith who published in 1776 , there were a lot of non - industrialized nations that you could introduce to your goods . So the more markets that opened up the more needed to be produced . Marx believed that workers standard of living decreased as people were moved into the cities to meet the demand for work . This resulted , he believed , in the workers and consumers becoming less self sufficient . Cheap goods require cheap labor . Instead of owning your own land or home , you lived in worker cities or rented in town . On this note Marx was not a big fan of private land ownership ( understatement , his summation of Communism was " The abolition of private property " ) . He argued that the land would be consolidated amongst the bourgeois and ultimately they would own the land / homes . We can see this today . Most people 's homes are owned by the bank , not by the family . If land was more communal you would n't having everyone paying rent to the same set of people who own the local land . Back to industrialization , this is the period of time where we find child labor , a lack of labor laws , unions , or anyone fighting for the workers themselves . Marx divided the population into two classes . The first was the bourgeois ( boor - zhwa ) who had the capital ( the money , the assets , the means to produce ) . These were the people who owned the companies or managed them . They did not produce directly , but the received the most profit from the production . The name basically means " in the walled city " . The second class was the proletariat . These are the workers in the factories and on the farms . Their standard of living is so low that they can only afford to survive . The name means " those who produce offspring " . They had enough to survive and reproduce . Now the proletariat the ones who are actually doing the work and producing the goods , yet they are treated the worst and receive little of the profits . Marx argued for a society in which the workers ruled . He argued for labor unions to protect themselves from increasingly poor conditions . Before unions , if a something happened to a worker , there was no one to represent them . People did n't want to lose their jobs defending them and there was n't much point to it . But if the workers band together and say , " Hey we are n't going to work unless you improve these conditions " well then the managers and owners would have to listen . They ca n't do the work on their own , they require a large number of the proletariat . The goal was for the workers to take advantage of their power , which was in production . question: Why does observing a particle change it ? Could this suggest that our minds are influencing reality or is it something else ? Explain like I'm five.

So when you 're " observing " anything at such a microscopic scale you 're by necessity " interacting " with it . Every photon it interacts with , every magnetic field it drifts through , every molecule it passes by , they 're all going to alter whatever you 're trying to observe . At the quantum scale observation and interaction are inseparable .

You ca n't measure anything without interacting it . Dipping a thermometer in a bath tub means that , depending on how hot or cold the thermometer itself is , the bath water 's temperature changes ever so slightly . There are no psionic abilities at play .

question: What is a thread in computing ? I looked it up on wikipedia and such , but I unfortunately still did not understand it . ELIF please ! Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: In the simplest form a thread one instruction set from many . A program can have multiple threads or instruction sets to compute and come back with an answer . Example , you have to build a lego castle and you invite 3 other friends . ( 4 total threads ) You are capable of building different parts of the castle at once as you spread the tasks among your friends . 1 gets to build the towers , one the walls , one the dungeon , and one the kings room or whatever else . Each person is a thread , once each finishes their task they are put together to provide the finished product . Trying to keep it as simplistic as possible .

The easiest explanation I can think of : * You know what a program is , right ? And you of course know that your computer can run multiple programs at a time . * Threads are a way of essentially making your computer run two or more programs in one -- that is , two or more ' chains of execution ' of the program code . In effect , threads are just subdivisions of programs that , and here 's the important part , run simultaneously ( or close to it ) .

It 's a thing that can run code at the same time as other code is being run . As an analogy , if you make dinner , then pay your bills , then do the laundry , you 're doing your chores on a single thread . But if you defrost chicken , pay your electric bill , sort laundry , put chicken in the pot , pay your phone bill , start a load of whites , cook some vegetables , pay your rent , then dry and fold the whites ... that 's multi - threaded . More than one thing being worked on at the same time .
chatgpt_answers:
A thread is a separate flow of execution within a program. Imagine that you have a program that needs to do several things at the same time. For example, a web browser needs to download web pages, display them, and respond to user input all at the same time. One way to accomplish this is to use threads.

Imagine that you have a recipe that requires you to do several things at the same time. For example, you need to bake a cake and boil some eggs. One way to do this is to divide the recipe into two separate tasks, one for baking the cake and one for boiling the eggs. You can then assign each task to a different person, and both people can work on their tasks simultaneously.

Threads work in a similar way. A program can create several threads, and each thread can work on a separate task at the same time. This can make the program run faster, because the computer's processor can switch back and forth between the different threads, allowing them to all make progress simultaneously.

The price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio is a valuation metric that compares a company's share price to its earnings per share. It helps investors gauge the relative value of a company and assess how much they should pay for each dollar of earnings.
To calculate the P/E ratio, divide the stock price by the earnings per share (EPS). EPS represents the amount of profit generated by each share of common stock outstanding.
For example, if Company X has a share price of $50 and an EPS of $5, then its P/E ratio would be 10 ($50/$5).
Here are some key points related to the calculation:
Net income: This refers to the total profit earned by a company after deducting all expenses.
Basic EPS: Calculated by dividing net income by the number of weighted average shares outstanding during the reporting period.
Diluted EPS: Adjusts basic EPS to account for potential dilution from options, warrants, or convertible securities.
Retained earnings: Accumulated profits that have not been distributed as dividends.
Stock price: Represents the current market value of a single share of stock on any given day.
Importance of industry comparison:
Industry comparison provides context when analyzing a company's performance. By comparing companies within the same sector or industry, we can identify trends and patterns among peers. It allows us to understand how well a particular company performs relative to others in its field.
Key factors influencing P/E ratios include growth prospects, profitability margins, competitive advantages, and macroeconomic conditions. A higher-than-average P/E ratio indicates investor confidence in future earnings growth; conversely, lower valuations may suggest concerns over growth potential or increased risk.

question: what part of the government governs the US post office?
human_answers: The United States Postal Service (USPS), also known as the Post Office and U.S. Mail, is an independent agency of the United States federal government responsible for providing postal service in the United States.
chatgpt_answers: The United States Postal Service (USPS) is an independent agency of the executive branch of the federal government of the United States. The USPS is not funded by tax dollars and operates on revenue generated by the sale of its products and services. It is headed by the Postmaster General, who is appointed by the President of the United States with the advice and consent of the Senate. The USPS is a self-supporting government enterprise, and is not reliant on annual appropriations from Congress to fund its operations.

It is funded through the sale of postal products and services, and does not receive tax dollars for its operating expenses. The USPS is led by the Postmaster General, who is appointed by the President of the United States with the advice and consent of the Senate.

The United States Postal Service (USPS) is an independent agency of the federal government responsible for providing postal service in the United States. It is not a part of any other government agency or department, and it operates under the authority of the United States Code.

The USPS is headed by a board of governors, which is responsible for setting policies and overseeing the operations of the agency. The board is appointed by the President of the United States and confirmed by the Senate. The USPS is also subject to oversight by Congress, which has the power to pass laws that affect the agency and its operations.

Although the USPS is a government agency, it is self-sustaining and does not receive tax dollars to fund its operations. Instead, it generates revenue through the sale of postal products and services.

an independent establishment within the executive branch of the federal government, and it is governed by a unique structure that sets it apart from other federal agencies.

Here's how the USPS is governed:

1. **Independent Agency**: The USPS is classified as an "independent establishment" under the U.S. Code, meaning it operates independently of the Cabinet departments but remains subject to oversight by the President and Congress.

2. **Postal Regulatory Commission (PRC)**: This is the primary regulatory body for the USPS. The PRC was established in 1970 and is responsible for regulating postal rates, services, and operations. It has five members appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate, serving non-renewable 5-year terms.

3. **Postmaster General**: The Postmaster General is the head of the USPS. They are nominated by the President and confirmed by the Senate. While they have operational control over the USPS, they must follow regulations set by the PRC.

4. **Congressional Oversight**: Congress exercises general oversight through legislative authority, including setting budgetary policies and enacting laws that affect the USPS. However, the USPS itself does not come under direct congressional control like many other federal agencies.

In summary, while the USPS is part of the federal government and reports to the President, it is governed primarily by the Postal Regulatory Commission and operated under the leadership of the Postmaster General. It functions as a semi-autonomous entity within the executive branch.

question: The difference of South Korea and North Korea ? Edit 1 : This is a serious question , thanks ! Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Before WWII ( well really the 1930s ) Korea was a unified country . The Peninsula of Korea was occupied by Japan during WWII . Once Germany surrendered , the Soviet Union shifted it 's military towards Japan ( with whom they had had a cease fire with during most of the rest of the war , something Hitler did n't count on when he invaded the Soviets ) and was pushing Japan out of the area when Japan surrendered . The current border between North Korea and South Korea is as far as the Soviets had gotten when the war ended . After the war , the Soviets refused to give up control over the territory they were occupying , so South Korea regained its independence with support of the US , while North Korea became a satellite state of the Soviet Union ( sort of like how Germany was divided between East and West at the end of the war , only less amicably , since there was no reason for Korea to be occupied at all ) . South Korea was rebuilt much like Japan or western Europe , while North Korea became a communist dictatorship . Eventually , North Korea decided they wanted Korea to become whole again , and they did this by invading South Korea ( probably at the ' suggestion ' of the Soviets ) . The UN declared this invasion illegal , and sent forces ( lead by the US ) to push back the North Korean forces . North Korea was supported by Soviet military hardware and personnel , and once the front lines pushed well into North Korea , used China to base their forces , since China was technically not a participant ( even though China calls the Korean war " The war against US aggression " or something like that ) . The fighting stopped with a Cease Fire that established the current borders , however , no peace treaty has ever been signed between the two Koreas and an official state of war still exists between them . Modern South Korea is very much like Japan , except instead of producing anime and bizarre gadgets and porn , they produce pro StarCraft players ( and have mandatory military service for all male citizens due to the state of war with North Korea ) . North Korea is basically the worst place on Earth to live as a common citizen out of all the places that have a stable and prominent government . The government controls all resources worth anything and allocates almost all of them to the military and a select elite in power .

Jaywalking means when someone walks on the street or sidewalk in a way that's not safe, or breaks the rules for walking. It‚Äôs kind of like playing tag but on the road!

- Watching for traffic lights.

- Walking on sidewalks instead of the street.
- Not running in front of cars.

These rules help everyone move safely through the city.

question: Why do mirrors reverse the reflection horizontally amd not vertically ? When you look into a mirror , why is it you see an image reversed from side to side and not up and down ? Edit : and * Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: I think /u / jkazimir provides a beautiful and elegant answer , but it might be a bit mind - bending for some readers . Let 's see if I can explain the concept in another way : When you look in a mirror , and raise your * * left * * hand , it looks like the reflection is raising its * * right * * hand . Woah , dude ! Except ... no it 's not . Because that thing in the mirror * is not really " you " * . What you 're looking at is simply a flat , super - reflective surface that 's bouncing photons of light back at your eyes . We * perceive * it as being a version of ourselves , because our brains are ' programmed ' to recognise faces and body parts , and other things we 've seen before . But this is really just an illusion ; there 's nothing coming from the mirror except * light * . When you raise your * * left * * hand , it is the * * left * * side of the mirror that reflects the change . If you move your * * right * * hand , it is the * * right * * side of the mirror that shows it . So you see , it 's doing * exactly what it should be doing * . It 's not actually reversing anything at all :-)

Beautiful answer to this : They do n't reverse vertically because they * * do n't actually " reverse " horizontally in the first place ! * * If you wish to contest this , please explain why turning your head 90 - deg " causes " the same perception . In other words , you are selectively ignoring the " horizontal reversal " upwards ; you perceive * mirror*-reversal for strictly the horizontal dimension but only what I shall call * " opposition - consistency " * reversal for the vertical . Two different forms of reversal there ! It 's purely psychological . They do , however , reverse * * front to back * * , that is , the * * rotationally independent third dimension to the other two . * * The " horizontal bias " perception is due to human experience of unbalanced forces / landscapes / gradients / other facts of life deriving from evolving gravity etc . being from left to right ; gravity is not relevant to the vertical dimension . TL;DR There is no vertical " reversal " because there is no " reversal " in * either * dimension , as all points are * * still opposite each other * * , and not closer to the other vert / horiz . sides of the mirror -which * does * happen in a camera projection or human eye !

The way that reflections work is that light bounces off an object and then reflects back to your eyes. When light reflects off a mirror, it bounces off in a straight line. If you were to hold a mirror in front of you and trace the path of the light with your finger, you would see that it goes straight from your finger, to the mirror, and then back to your eye. Now, let's think about what would happen if the mirror reversed the image vertically instead of horizontally. When you look at an object, the top of the object is usually above the bottom. But if the mirror reversed the image vertically, the top of the object would be below the bottom, which doesn't make sense. On the other hand, if the mirror reversed the image horizontally, the left side of the object would be on the right side of the reflection, which does make sense. So, to sum it up, mirrors reflect images horizontally because it makes more sense to us when the left side of an object is on the right side of the reflection.

question: What 's the real difference between bottled water and tap water ? Bottled water gives me the worst stomach pains and makes me sick . Tap water never does this . Is n't water just water ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Water is indeed not just water . I do n't know much about the regulations in other countries , but here in The Netherlands bottled water is of a lower quality than tap water . Before water comes out of the faucet it 'll get ' cleaned ' . They remove a lot of particles in different ways . The water used for tap water can be from the surface , but can also be from deep in the ground . The water from deep in the ground needs less filtering , this is why bottled water is usually made from this water . The tap water here is way cheaper because if the government funds it . The tap water would be way more expensive than bottled water . If you would drink pure water , you would die because of what is called reverse osmosis . Osmosis is a process happening in your kidneys . The salt in your blood goes through a membrane to your urine . This happens because the salt level in your blood is higher than in your urine . If you drink pure water the salt level in your blood goes down and the salt from your urine goes back . And you 'll poison yourself .

The main difference , speaking broadly across all brands ( at least in the US ) , the primary difference is one is in a bottle . To be a little more specific , bottled water * can * have different water sources depending on brand but a lot of US bottled water is actually municipal treated water ( tap water ) that has been bottled in a factory for sale . Sometimes they do additional purification , although this is not required or universally true . Sometimes they do add trace ingredients ( minerals and such ) supposedly for taste , but in blind taste tests the vast majority of people ca n't tell the difference between bottled water and tap water so that 's a bit dubious in my eyes . The biggest difference in my opinion actually boils down to regulation . In the US , tap water is regulated by the EPA , whereas bottled water is regulated by the FDA . The EPA has a lot of tight regulations and often has dedicated individuals responsible for regular inspections and testing of tap water , whereas the FDA does n't really dedicate anyone specifically to bottled water . Ultimately , the difference between tap water and bottled water overall is fairly minimal , however bottled water quality is probably more uniform across the country than tap water . The tap water in some areas will be significantly better or worse ( or simply different depending on the method of treatment ) . Depending on where you live the tap water or the bottled water could end up being a little bit better - I grew up in Oregon and I always thought bottled water tasted far worse , but after traveling around ( especially up and down the East coast ) there are definitely areas where I 'd consider the tap water worse than bottled water . tl;dr : Speaking generally there 's no fundamental difference , and some bottled water is in fact just tap water . Depending on the quality of tap water in your area the bottled water could be better , worse , or roughly on par . YMMV .

The differences between water types are usually not things that " should " make you sick-- it 's bullshit that bottled water is " safer " ( it 's not tested or regulated more or better than tap water ) , but if bottled water was shipping with E. Coli or Giardia in it , everybody would hear about it and that water would likely be recalled . There is also concern that the plastic may be bad but this is more of a long - term issue and whether it 's legitimate at all is controversial . In reality it 's probably the taste that 's unfamiliar and causes your body to react badly . That may be " all in your head " but does n't mean the effect is n't real ! Some other factors that do n't make it unsafe but might make it distasteful would be temperature of the water , and the overall appearance and experience of drinking from a plastic bottle . All of these are shown to change people 's satisfaction with a beverage .

question: Why does a computer need to be cooled ? Why ca n't we just create a processor that generates no heat ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Because every electrical current causes warmth due to resistance .

At quantify a little bit of what people are saying . I 've heard that processors can have around 50 amps going through them . Considering that power lost through resistance is P = I^2 R , and that R is a function of a few variables , but importantly , is inversely proportional to radius of the wire it 's travelling through , so the smaller the wire , the larger the resistance . So a large current and small radius both combine to produce large power loss . That generates heat . Heat increases resistance also , so without cooling , you would get a run away effect until something failed .

The processor works by sending a lot of electrical signals back and froth . Which creates heat , there is no way around that . You can of course reduce the heat by reducing the power , but that also reduces the speed at which you can run it . For example a phone processor does n't get as hot , but it 's also much slower .

question: What are the tax implications if I do some work for a company for trade, rather than pay?
human_answers: Bartering is a tricky discussion. Yes, it definitely applies when you are self-employed and do a job that you would charge anyone else for, but what if you are helping a friend in your spare time? If you receive something in exchange, the value of the item you received would be your income, but what if you don't receive anything in exchange? If the company bought a computer that they loan to you to do occasional work for them, there's no reason you couldn't take the computer home and have that company retain ownership of the property. They could still expense the depreciation of the computer without giving it to you. If it were a car though, you would have to count mileage for personal use as income. What if you exchange occasional tech support for the use of an empty desk and Internet connection? As long as they aren't renting desks for money to others, there's probably no additional marginal cost to them if they allow you to use the space, so the fair market value question breaks down.

The value of the goods or services that you receive in trade is taxable as income, and must be reported on your tax return.For example, if you perform $1,000 worth of work for a company in exchange for $1,000 worth of goods or services, you must report the value of the goods or services as income on your tax return.It's important to keep accurate records of the value of the goods or services that you receive in trade, as you may need to provide documentation to the IRS if you are audited. You should also be aware that you may be subject to self-employment taxes if you engage in a significant amount of bartering.If you have any specific questions about the tax implications of bartering, you should consult with a tax professional or the IRS.

Okay, let's break down the tax implications of doing work for trade instead of paying cash. This is generally considered an exchange or barter transaction.

Here's what typically happens from a US federal income tax perspective:

**1. Basis:**  
The key concept is "basis." You contribute services (work) to the business. In this case, your basis in the stock received as payment isn't zero like it would be with cash contributions; instead, it's based on the *fair market value* of the services you provided at the time they were given.  

**2. Fair Market Value (FMV):**  
For IRS purposes, compensation paid by a corporation through services has a deemed fair market value. This means even though no money changed hands, there's an assumed monetary value placed on the service. FMV is defined as:  
*   The price at which the property would change hands between a willing buyer and a willing seller, neither being under compulsion to buy or sell and both having reasonable knowledge of relevant facts.*  
In practice, determining the FMV of services can sometimes be tricky but needs to be done consistently. Factors might include comparable cash salary rates for similar work in the industry/marketplace.  

**3. Compensation Income:**  
Generally, the value of the stock received in exchange for services is treated as taxable compensation to you personally. You must report that amount as wages or other compensation on your individual income tax return (Form W-2 or 1099-MISC/Form 1099-NEC depending on the situation).  

**4. Corporate Benefit:**  
Conversely, the corporation benefits from receiving your services. They have an expense deduction related to the services performed

question: How do you test something for randomness ? I read this : URL_0 and I 'm still a little baffled I guess . For instance , if I mix up a Rubik 's Cube , how could someone test if it was truly random or not ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Randomness usually means unpredictability . It 's hard to prove that something is random . But , it 's easy to show something is NOT truly random . Let 's say someone shuffles a deck of cards and then shows you the top card . More specifically , let 's say they do this a trillion times in a row . After each shuffle and display , you write down which card they showed . You would expect that after each shuffle , every card would have the same chance of ending up on the top of the deck . So , after the trillion retries , you look over your notes and see whether this is the case . If each card shows up in your list about 1/52 of the time then you can say the shuffling was pretty well randomized . If the King of Hearts shows up 95 % of the time , then you would assume that something is funny with the shuffling technique . Likewise , if you can begin to predict which card will appear , then that definitely indicates it is not truly random . If you see from your list that the same pattern of cards ALWAYS repeats then that is a sign that the shuffle is not truly random . If you handed someone a Rubik 's Cube then they could n't really say whether your mix up was random or not . But , if you did it a bunch of times and no pattern emerged then they could say you were mixing it randomly .

Reminds me of a joke : a brilliant computer scientist claims to have invented a computer that can generate truly random numbers ( not psuedorandom , but truly random ) . He assembles a room full of mathematicians and scientists to demonstrate it . He asks the machine to give him a truly random number . The machine responds " 1 " . Someone else in the room asks for another truly random number . The machine responds " 1 " . A third person in the room asks for another truly random number , and the machine responds " 1 " . At this point , everyone turns a cynical eye on the inventor and someone asks , " are you * sure * these numbers are truly random ? " The inventor replies , " well , that 's the problem with truly random numbers , it 's impossible to tell . " On a more serious note , in your Rubik 's Cube example , there are only a finite number of positions that it 's possible for a Rubik 's Cube to be turned to , so the " randomness " of any given starting position is just one divided by the total number of possibilities .

gndn 's joke is very on point to your question . Testing for randomness is very difficult in general . Testing a single sample for randomness is completely impossible . For example , you ask me to guess an integer between one and a million , and I say " 4 " . It * seems * to you that I did n't really select the number at random . After all , if you inspected a lot of random numbers in that interval , most of them would have six digits , so a small number like " 4 " seems rather unlikely . But mathematically , every number in the interval is equally likely , since that 's what randomness implies . So the number certainly could have been " 4 " . Or even " 1 " . Or " 999,999 " . You simply have n't seen enough examples to have any way to gauge whether or not my method of randomly selecting numbers seems to be a good one . And even if you have a large number of samples , there 's always the possibility that pure dumb chance has resulted in a " funny looking " set of numbers coming out of a good , random number generator . With a large sample it will be * improbable * for this to happen , but it wo n't be * impossible * . So your tests of randomness can only provide * chances * that the set of results was not random , not certainty .

question: Please explain what is "Oxford University Press"
human_answers:
Oxford University Press (OUP) is the university press of the University of Oxford. It is the largest university press in the world, and its printing history dates back to the 1480s. Having been officially granted the legal right to print books by decree in 1586, it is the second oldest university press after Cambridge University Press.
It is a department of the University of Oxford and is governed by a group of 15 academics known as the Delegates of the Press, who are appointed by the vice-chancellor of the University of Oxford. The Delegates of the Press are led by the Secretary to the Delegates, who serves as OUP's chief executive and as its major representative on other university bodies. Oxford University Press has had a similar governance structure since the 17th century. The press is located on Walton Street, Oxford, opposite Somerville College, in the inner suburb of Jericho.
For the last 500 years, OUP has primarily focused on the publication of pedagogical texts and continues this tradition today by publishing academic journals, dictionaries, English language resources, bibliographies, books on indology, music, classics, literature, history, as well as bibles and atlases.
OUP has offices throughout the world, primarily in locations that were once part of the British Empire (mainly India and the United States).

It is a not-for-profit organization and its main goal is to further the University's objectives of excellence in research, scholarship, and education. OUP publishes a wide range of materials, including dictionaries, textbooks, scholarly monographs, and research journals in a variety of languages and disciplines. It has offices in more than 50 countries and its products are sold in over 180 countries.

question: Why should n't you induce vomiting after ingesting poison ? I was reading the back of a poison bottle and it said ' If consumed do not induce vomiting . Drink a glass of water ' Why is it so ? Does water break up the poison ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Vomiting has the potential to increase the damage of the throat and esophagus which the poison has damaged on the way down . Keeping the poison in the stomach and , in this case , diluting it , helps limit the damage . The stomach is a pretty harsh environment and is typically acidic , so it can handle , to a limited degree , acidic and basic , ( meaning alkali or caustic ) , poisons .

Another problem with some toxins is * aspiration * . There is a reasonable chance that , in attempting to vomit up the substance , some of it might get breathed into the lungs . The esophagus and stomach are relatively sturdy - the lungs are very fragile .

Treatment depends mainly on the type of poison . For many poisons , inducing vomiting * is * the preferred treatment . But for corrosives , the damage done by puking it up can be worse than keeping it in , but diluting it . Dilution can buy you time to get to a hospital where the stomach can be properly pumped .

Drinking a glass of water after swallowing poison may help to dilute the poison, which can help to reduce the risk of harm. However, it's important to note that this is not always effective, and seeking medical attention as soon as possible is always the best course of action if you or someone else has swallowed poison.

- **Contribution to a Partnership or Corporation**: May involve different rules depending on whether the transferor is contributing property to a new entity or to an existing one.
- **Asset Purchase vs. Stock Purchase**: In stock purchases, only the shareholder‚Äôs tax basis changes; in asset purchases, the buyer assumes the seller's tax liabilities.

---

question: Why is computer memory always a power of two ? ie Why ca n't I buy a 5 GB usb memory stick ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: The way that computers work is based on what 's called " binary . " It 's based on how things like transistors and other electronics are able to work . But , for simplicity 's sake , imagine each bit like a switch connected to a lightbulb . If the switch is " on " the lightbulb is on , if the switch is " off " the lightbulb is off . It can either be " 1 " ( on ) or " 0 " ( off ) . If you have one switch , you have two states it can be in . With two switches , you have four states . With three switches , you have eight , then sixteen , 32 , etc . Every additional " switch " can only possibly add combinations in a power of two . And the way computers read data is ( essentially ) reading which switches in which order are on .

The other answers are almost there - they explain why powers of two are common in PCs but not why flash / RAM chips are made to powers of two . Every time your computer wants to access something from its memory , it looks up the address ( exactly like a postal address ) and then " copys " the data from that memory . If we think of postal addresses , then with 1 number we can get 10 addresses ( 0 - 9 ) , with 2 we can get 100 ( 0 - 99 ) etc . Remember how computers work in 1 and 0 's , for each number or ' bit ' in the address we can talk to 2^n addresses . For computer chips this means we usually fill up all those 2^n addresses with useful stuff , so that we do n't waste the electronics required for addresses . So RAM , and flash * * chips * * ( flash is used in USB drives ) are usually 2^n bytes . Hard drives on the other hand are not restricted by chip electronics but by the accuracy of their motors and the physical size and number of their disks . So you often see hard drives with 700 GB , or 1.5 TB or other " odd " sizes not a power of 2 .

I think you may be confusing memory and storage , but I 'll try to explain both . Memory is closely tied to the CPU , so making their size a power of two means that multiple modules can be packed requiring a minimum of logic in order to switch between them . Keep in mind everything you do on a computer is interpreted from binary , either 1 or 0 . 1 binary digit = = 1 bit . A byte is eight bits , resulting in the possibility of 256 values ( 28 ) . A kilobyte is 1,024 ( 210 ) bytes ( the term " byte " is often defined as a collection of bits rather than the strict definition of an 8 - bit quantity . ) The term memory refers to the amount of RAM installed in the computer , whereas the term storage refers to the capacity of the computer ‚Äôs hard disk . Computers only understand 1 's and 0 's . Because of this , most hardware manufacturers increase the capacity accordingly . It is more economical to do it this way , although you can find some rare flash drives with odd capacity , they are most likely ones that have their memory damaged and/or disabled . Source : Computer Science Major

Because computers use binary code to store and retrieve information, it is easier for them to work with memory sizes that can be represented in binary code using a small number of ones and zeros.

Powers of two, such as 2, 4, 8, 16, 32, and so on, can be represented using a small number of ones and zeros in binary code. For example, the number 8 can be represented as 1000 in binary code (which is 12^3 + 02^2 + 02^1 + 02^0). This is why computer memory is often sold in sizes that are powers of two, like 4 GB or 8 GB.

It is possible to buy a 5 GB memory stick, but it might not be as common because it is not a power of two and therefore might not be as easy for a computer to work with.

question: Why do so many atheists think that science and religion are opposites ? Please do n't say something like , " Because it 's true . " and then downvote me , because I actually want a legitimate answer . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: As a scientist , you are constantly trying to disprove evidence . To do this evidence must exist in the first place , science is driven by evidence and so a scientists mind should also be rational , logical and evidence driven . If a scientist believed in god it would go against the way science should be practiced , they would be believing that something is true even though they hold no evidence on the matter . Science is about conditional belief backed up by evidence . Religion is about unconditional belief with a lack of evidence .
Because most religions require you take things on * faith * , while science requires only that you have an open mind and judge things based on evidence .

Science only concerns knowledge that can be tested and verified . Religion can never be verified by scientific fact . Therefore religion and science are in seperate realms , and will not overlap . They are not direct opposites ; it 's more like comparing apples to oranges ( literally ) . Both are different from each other , but you would n't say they are " opposite " . On a side note , it 's worth pointing out that science and religion are not incompatible . Science does not " disprove " religion , nor should ( although some more extreme religions would disagree ) religion contradict science . Believing in religion does not automatically make one " unscientific . " tl;dr - Religion relies on faith , Science relies on reason . Both are different but not opposite or contradictory .

Like /u / kabajingai said , you can type the entire romanization out to get your desired word . However , this is pretty time - consuming , so most people usually remove the tone numbers when typing . You can go even further and shorten a word like ÊúãÂèã , peng2you5 ( friend ) to just " py " because " py " is not a valid syllable so the system recognizes it as an abbreviation . 2 . Zhuyin / Bopomofo : This system was used in China before the standard Latin phonetic transcription came about in the 1950s , but now it is only used in Taiwan . It functions in the same as pinyin , but instead of Latin letters , you have distorted Chinese characters that almost resemble Japanese katakana . Each symbol represents a specific morpheme , and tonal marks similar to those in pinyin are used to represent the tones . 3 . Wubihua : The first two systems were phonetically - based , but this one is handwriting - based . All Chinese characters have a standard stroke order ( order of the lines you have to draw to make the character ) , and there are only five buttons in this system you can press to get your desired character . There are ~34 types of strokes in Chinese , but some of them are very similar to each other , so Wubihua classifies the 34 strokes into either a horizontal , vertical , falling to the left , falling to the right / dots , and turning strokes ( which are a combination of any of the previously four as long as you do n't lift the pencil when writing ) . 4 . Wubi and Cangjie : These are also writing - based , but instead use the radicals that make up the characters . These are more complicated to learn as a beginner because the rules and algorithms might seem a bit strange at first . question: If the universe is mostly hydrogen , how come the Earth is iron , silicon etc ? self explanatory title Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: All of the heavier elements were fused together from lighter elements inside dying stars . Those stars exploded , and that material eventually became us . We are star - stuff , as Carl Sagan liked to say .

Hydrogen is extremely light . This means that a helium molecule travels , on average , much faster than the heavier elements found in our atmosphere . It happens that the Earth 's gravitational pull is not enough to keep the hydrogen well confined , so atmospheric hydrogen is constantly leaking into space . In fact , none of the smaller planets ( Earth , Venus , Mars , Mercury ) have a strong enough gravitational field , and so none of them contain very much free molecular hydrogen . The gas giants , on the other hand , * are * heavy enough to hold on to their hydrogen .

Fusion inside of living stars converts hydrogen into heavier and heavier elements up to , I think , iron . To get past iron , I believe you need a nova . Conveniently , novas are also really good at spreading around the fused contents of old stars . The Earth is formed from some of the remains of an exploded star . As are you .
chatgpt_answers:
The Earth is made up of many different elements, not just iron and silicon. In fact, the most abundant element in the Earth's crust is oxygen, followed by silicon, aluminum, iron, calcium, sodium, potassium and magnesium. These elements are not found in the same proportions throughout the universe, because the conditions that led to the formation of the Earth were different from those that exist in most of the rest of the universe.

When the universe was first created, it was made up mostly of hydrogen and helium, with small amounts of other elements. Over time, these elements combined to form stars, which are massive balls of gas that are held together by their own gravity. Inside a star, the temperature and pressure are so high that hydrogen atoms can fuse together to form heavier elements like helium, carbon, oxygen and so on. This process, called nuclear fusion, releases a tremendous amount of energy, which is what makes stars shine.

When a star like the Sun runs out of hydrogen to fuse, it begins to cool down and eventually collapses. This can lead to the formation of a new star, or it can lead to the creation of a planet like Earth. As the collapsed star cools down, the heavier elements like iron and silicon tend to sink to the center, while lighter elements like hydrogen and helium stay near the surface. This is why the Earth is made up of mostly heavier elements, even though the universe as a whole is mostly hydrogen.

Peak oil , an event based on M. King Hubbert 's theory , is the point in time when the maximum rate of extraction of petroleum is reached , after which it is expected to enter terminal decline.[1 ] Peak oil theory is based on the observed rise , peak , fall , and depletion of aggregate production rate in oil fields over time . It is often confused with oil depletion ; however , peak oil is the point of maximum production , while depletion refers to a period of falling reserves and supply . Some observers , such as petroleum industry experts Kenneth S. Deffeyes and Matthew Simmons , predict negative global economy implications following a post - peak production decline and subsequent oil price increase because of the high dependence of most modern industrial transport , agricultural , and industrial systems on the low cost and high availability of oil.[2][3 ] Predictions vary greatly as to what exactly these negative effects would be . Oil production forecasts on which predictions of peak oil are based are often made within a range which includes optimistic ( higher production ) and pessimistic ( lower production ) scenarios . Optimistic[4 ] estimations of peak production forecast the global decline will begin after 2020 , and assume major investments in alternatives will occur before a crisis , without requiring major changes in the lifestyle of heavily oil - consuming nations . Pessimistic predictions of future oil production made after 2007 stated either that the peak had already occurred,[5][6][7][8 ] that oil production was on the cusp of the peak , or that it would occur shortly.[9][10 ] Hubbert 's original prediction that US peak oil would be in about 1970 seemed accurate for a time , as US average annual production peaked in 1970 at 9.6 million barrels per day.[11 ] However , the successful application of massive hydraulic fracturing to additional tight reservoirs caused US production to rebound , challenging the inevitability of post - peak decline for the US oil production.[12 ] In addition , Hubbert 's original predictions for world peak oil production proved premature.[4 ] In short , " Peak Oil " is the way of all non - renewable resources . Unless we slow down and get local relationships and treat each other more like family , we run out really really fast . question: Can someone explain Anarchism to me ? LI5 I do n't get it . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Anarchism does n't mean no rules . It means no hierarchy . I do n't know of a serious political philosophy that advocates no rules . At the moment , our rules come from our leaders . In a totalitarian society , it 's as simple as that . In a democratic one like America , the leaders need to pay some heed to the citizens and motivated citizens are able to influence those rules to an extent but the extent is very limited . Be wary of anyone who maintains America is a police state or that it is a democratic republic rather than a democracy . The former has no clue about what they are talking about and the latter is resting on a semantic quibble . Anarchists ( and Libertarians in the American sense ) see the state as a centre of power where it is concentrated in the hands of a few . Sure , you could go to college , join some young Labor / Republican / Democrat / Liberal group , become a lawyer and get on track to join this elite from the beginning but much of your ability to do this is determined by luck . More so than most people recognise . And even if you succeed , it still does n't solve the problem of power being concentrated in the hands of people at the centre of the state 's structure . Until Rothbard and some other American thinkers became prominent last century , the term Libertarian was more akin to what we think of as anarchist today . That is why I make the distinction of American - style libertarians . Those libertarians and the anarchists agree that the state is mostly malevolent but after that , they part ways . Libertarians feel the single best improvement is the minimisation of the state and things will all be great after that . Anarchists are just as derisive of the state but feel there are other hierarchies that are just as , if not more , detrimental than the state . Religious authorities and corporations for example . This is not to say anarchists are * necessarily * atheist or anti - business . Tolstoy was a devout Christian and espoused a style of anarchism that thrived while he was alive . The point is that the religious authority should n't be vested in a pope or caliph and should look more like the Quakers for example . Also , the rewards of business should n't accrue to a shareholder / boss class . Profits should be shared by the producers of goods and services . Another difference is with the view of land ownership . Libertarians feel land is just another kind of property and almost all of it should be held in private hands . Most anarchists feel land is the main type of property that must not be held privately . All land is stolen from someone , or bought from someone who stole it or bought from someone who may not have stolen it but acquired it without work via inheritance . Anarchists feel all property should have rents paid back to the community . Georgists for example believe these rents should constitute the only type of tax allowed in a Georgist community . A general principle is that power should devolve to the lowest possible organisational level . This is one of the stated objectives of the EU but they do n't prioritise it as highly as anarchists . If I want to smoke weed , it should be for me to decide whether I will or not . On the other hand , the lights in my street are what economists call a public good and so it would n't be in my self - interest to set them all up and maintain them myself . In that case , that task would fall to the neighbourhood council . There might only be a few hundred people covered by that council 's borders so I could have real influence in its decisions without quitting my day job and becoming part of a dedicated political class . That council might also coordinate the neighbourhood 's creche , meals for the housebound and so on . The next neighbourhood over might be overwhelmingly from a particular immigrant community and might come to a consensus to conduct its business in that group ' language . However , they might be interested in a football stadium , high school or some other infrastructure that would be too big for a neighbourhood collective to handle on its own . So a group of neighbourhoods who wish to remain distinct but feel they can work together would build confederations to handle that sort of thing . Rinse and repeat and you could have Universities or Large Hadron Colliders .

Anarchism is an Ideology in which people are against any form of domination . That is social domination in which some classes are wealthier than others , political domination in which a person or group of people are leaders of an entity , and cultural domination in which our ethics and morals are influenced by the ruling class . Instead Anarchism promotes rational thinking and personal freedoms ( Not the same personal freedoms as Libertarians who promote free market , for Anarchists , having a free market brings the domination of richer poeple over poorer ones . ) It would be difficult to maintain such a society so Anarchists beleive that people should live in relatively small communities in which resources are shared rationaly ( not necessarily equaly ) and where decisions are taken democratically by rational thinking people who are free from dominations .

Any community where no system of government exists . There is no elected leader , or controlling force . It 's essentially all based on the honor system and/or balance of power . I wo n't murder you , if you do n't murder me .
