question: Helicopter autorotation How does it work that helicopters can do all their regular flight / landing when their engine power is cut ? Does it involve the kinetic energy of the blades ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Helicopters use what is known as collective pitch , long story short this means that the rotor blades can have both negative and positive pitch and can thus blow wind upwards ( negative ) or downwards ( positive ) . When a helicopter enters a autorotation the rotor is disconnected from the power source ( to allow the rotors to freely rotate ) and the pilot adds negative pitch to the rotor blades , this causes the blades to speed up as the helicopter moves through the air towards the ground ( this energy will be used later ) . At a certain distance above the ground the pilot adds positive pitch to the rotor blades , the causing them to blow wind downwards and thus slowing the descent of the helicopter and enabling it to land safely

When the engine loses power , the pilot lowers the collective , turning the rotor into a pinwheel . This creates some drag ( slowing the descent ) while simultaneously keeping the blades spinning at a constant rate . question: why do sirens change pitch so significantly when you drive by them ? Not the general siren sound but how when you drive by as soon as you pass by it it seems to lower a key or two . Edit : thanks for the answers ! Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: You 're thinking of the Doppler Effect URL_0 Basically , the forward motion of the vehicle makes the siren sound waves closer together which increases their frequency ( pitch ) . As the vehicle gets further away , the sounds trail off because the waves of the siren are further apart .

The siren makes sound waves in the air , picture waves sorta like on the ocean . When you are approaching the siren , or the siren is approaching you , then the distance between these waves is shortened . Each one is being emitted from closer to you , so the travel time of the waves to your ear is closer together than it would be if you were stationary , which raises the pitch . Once you pass it , the opposite occurs . The source is getting further away , so the distance between the waves as they reach your ear is becoming stretched out .

The phenomenon you 're hearing as a siren changes pitches while passing you at high speed is called the Doppler effect . Think of sound as a bunch of waves , because it is , and when a sound - emitting object is traveling quickly towards you , those waves are more smushed together , creating a higher pitch . After the object ( a siren , train , whatever ) passes you , it 's now moving at a high rate of speed away from you , and the sound waves that hit your ears are more spread out , resulting in a lower pitch .
chatgpt_answers:
When you are driving by a siren, the pitch of the sound seems to change because of something called the Doppler effect. The Doppler effect is a change in the frequency or pitch of a sound wave that occurs when the source of the sound and the listener are moving relative to each other. 
For example, when a siren on an ambulance is approaching you, the sound waves it is emitting are compressed, or squeezed together. This makes the pitch of the siren sound higher. As the ambulance passes by you and moves away, the sound waves it is emitting are stretched out, which makes the pitch of the siren sound lower. 
This is similar to what happens when a car with a loud horn drives by you. The pitch of the horn seems to change as the car approaches and then moves away from you. 
So, when you are driving by a siren, the pitch of the sound seems to change because the source of the sound (the ambulance or fire truck) is moving relative to you, and the Doppler effect causes the pitch of the sound to change.

Additionally, the thin air at high altitudes can make it harder for the rocket to lift off the ground and can cause other problems during the launch.

Overall, the combination of the boost from Earth's rotation and the fact that Cape Canaveral has a lot of infrastructure (like launch pads and control centers) already in place makes it a good choice for launching rockets.

question: How come heat seeking missiles do n't go straight to the sun ? It is the thing with most heat ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Older versions of the AIM-9 Sidewinder did routinely lock on to the Sun or clouds , sending them ballistic . Newer versions have corrected this by adding optical filters to the sensor to only allow certain bands of infrared energy into the sensor for detection . This same system is used to help defeat flare countermeasures .

The field of vision on a heat seeking missile is generally pretty narrow so that it does n't go after the wrong target . If it ca n't see the Sun it ca n't switch targets and lock onto the Sun . Plus more modern heat seekers are " smarter " than older heat seekers and are less likely to get confused by other heat sources .

Heat seeking missiles have a very narrow field of view in their heat ( infrared radiation ) sensor . They can pivot the sensor though . When a missile is not tracking yet , it is scanning an area in front with that sensor for potential heat sources it could go after . This is why it takes some time for a missile to lock on . Modern missiles tracking heads can be pointed at a heat source that is off the center line , and lock on . Once locked on , the tracking head is pointing at the heat source , and tries to navigate the missile in a way that it can keep looking at the heat source . There 's two ways to get a heat seeking missile break the lock . One is if the missile can not manoeuvre enough to keep the tracking head looking at the target . If the target is out of sight , the missile will just do random stuff ( as in keep going straight until the fuel is depleted or the missile self - destructs ) The other one is to present the heat sensor a more attractive target ... there 's a lot of theory to it , but on older missiles it boils down to : something hotter in sight . This can be a magnesium flare dropped by the target , it can as well be the Sun . Also , if you point your missile at the Sun , or if your target is close to the Sun from the missile 's image sensor 's point of view , it will happily lock on to the Sun instead of the less hot actual target . Modern missile tracking systems avoid this issue by using imaging infrared . They do n't simply go after the hottest thing around , but instead take an infrared video and match the temperatures and shapes of objects . While the Sun or a magnesium flare basically looks like a hot circle on the image , an aircraft looks very much different . There 's cones of hot to warm air behind the engines , there 's the engines themselves in front of the cones , there 's electronics around the pilot and there 's also the leading edges of the wings and stabilizers that heat up by friction .

In addition, the sun is constantly moving through the sky, so even if the missile could reach it, it would be difficult to follow and hit the sun as it moves across the sky.

So, while the sun is the source of a lot of heat, it is not a practical target for a heat-seeking missile because it is too far away and too hot to be accurately detected and tracked.

question: how does money enter circulation ? I know that money is printed but how do they get it into circulation ? Who gets the free money ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Newly made money in the US is handled by the Federal Reserve . Large banks already have reserves of cash and branches of the banks are supplied the money from there . When demand for cash increases banks will " purchase " or lend more money from the federal reserve bank . When demand is low cash is returned to the Reserve Bank where it will be destroyed if it is past its lifetime and replaced with the new bills / coin

Banks do n't keep all their cash on hand . In the US they deposit it with the federal reserve . The Fed evaluates bills to see if they are in good enough shape to remain in circulation . If not then those bills are replaced with newly printed ones . When another bank 's cash is running low they withdraw money from the Fed and get a mix of new and old bills .

There is more than one way money is put into the money supply or created . When federal bonds are bought and sold , money is moved in and out of the supply . When the public buys bonds , the money they used to buy them is taken out of the supply . Likewise , when the public sells a mature bond back to the government , money is put into the supply . The other way money is created is when you deposit money in the bank . When a deposit is made , some portion of that deposit is loaned out by the bank and deposited somewhere else . This process repeats and is called the money multiplier .

The symptoms you describe are highly suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). GERD is caused by chronic reflux of acid into your esophagus.
Reflux occurs due to increased intra-abdominal pressure that forces acid upwards through an incompetent lower esophageal sphincter (LES). The LES is a muscle that keeps the stomach separated from the esophagus. Normally, it functions as a one-way valve between these two areas. However, in many patients who have a hernia, obesity, hiatal hernias or pregnancy, the function of this muscle may be impaired.
If you had an upper endoscopy performed, this would confirm the diagnosis of GERD. Also, if there was active erosive disease on biopsy, treatment should include twice daily use of antacid (Ranitidine, Zantac) or proton pump inhibitor medications (PPIs like Prilosec, Nexium, Prevacid).

Doing your best, on the other hand, means trying your hardest and striving for excellence, but also accepting that mistakes and imperfections are a natural part of the process. It means being proud of what you have achieved, even if it is not perfect.

You might even give up on the drawing altogether because it is not perfect. If you are just trying your best, you might still strive to make your drawing as good as possible, but you will also be proud of what you have created, even if it is not perfect.

The factorial of an integer n, denoted by n!, is the product of all positive integers less than or equal to n. For example, 4! (four factorial) equals the product of the first four whole numbers: 24 (i.e., 1 √ó 2 √ó 3 √ó 4). By convention, zero factorial (0!) is defined as 120 (i.e., 1).
The factorial operation is encountered in many areas of mathematics, notably in combinatorics, algebra, analysis, and the theory of finite groups. It allows a short expression for the number of n-permutations of nn objects. In elementary probability theory, it allows fast computation of probabilities based on tree structures, for example in deciding what move to make with the best odds of winning at the end of a chess game when there are only two pieces left, each piece with its own set of possible moves.

- Factorial of n (written as n!) means multiplying all positive numbers from n down to 1.
- For example: 
    - 4! = 4 √ó 3 √ó 2 √ó 1 = 24
    - 3! = 3 √ó 2 √ó 1 = 6

But what about zero? And what does it mean if something equals itself?

**What is 0!?**
Let's think about how factorial works:
- 1! = 1 √ó nothing? Actually, by definition, we say 1! has only one number to multiply, so just 1.

Now, imagine having no objects at all in a group. How many ways can you arrange them?
You can't have any arrangement because there's nothing to do or order with!
However, mathematicians decided that this situation still should be considered as "one way" ‚Äî meaning there's exactly **zero arrangements**, but they give it value 1 because it makes math work nicely without breaking rules.

So, **0! is defined as 1** to show that arranging an empty set is possible (even though not really) and sets a base rule for things like permutations.

**What is 1! then?**
For one object, like one apple, how many ways can you arrange it?
Only **one way**: put the single apple on the table. So logically, 1! must equal 1.

human_answers: Salt is useful as a preservative . Preserved food means you can travel farther at sea and keep a reliable source of food for your army . Also it just tastes good . We like it . At no point when you re dying of salt deficiency do you crave salt , which means we sought it just because we like it , at least at first . Its the only rock we eat and lots of cultures attributed spiritual meaning to it as well . Most cultures with access to seawater did dry brines and scrape up the salt but it 's a surprisingly labor and energy intensive process if you want to produce it in any meaningful amount . Dryng it in the sun usually involved enormous clay basins which were raked for crystals as they formed on the surface . you could just splash brine on a hot rock and wait for it to dry but it produces uneven and impure salt and not a lot . The Romans would make big clay pots and fill them with brine then cook them dry , repeating the process over and over then breaking the pot open . Again , labor intensive but it produced a purer crystal . I can go on and on about salt . I 'm a huge nerd about it but for now , TLDR Salt is tasty and useful , and you can get it from evaporating brine but it takes a long time and more effort than you 'd think . Edit : why it was rare right up until the end of the 1800s has mostly to do with mining technology . We can find it and get to it easier now and we can build big pan vacuums to make all the sea salt we need .

Not everyone was near the ocean and i beleieve it takes a good amout of time / effort to make it and then haul it . A LOT of salt was needed to preserve/ flavour foods so it was very valuable . I could be wrong , this question is likely on google .

question: What makes a good starting , relieving , and closing pitcher ? What is the skill set / personality required for each type of pitcher ? Why do some pitchers make good starting pitchers , while others make an entire career closing games ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Your starters are going to be your versatile workhorses . Able to throw 100 + pitches and/or at least 6 innings or so every 5 - 6 days , with a variety of pitches to maximize their time in the game before they get figured out . Relievers are your middle guys who can go an inning or two like a starter , but nowadays are more specialized . You have your " specialists " who come in to get out one kind of batter ( lefties , for example ) . Come in , throw hard , get outs , get out . Setup men are like a closer , but without the title . The " bridge " to your closer . Closers come in in a high pressure situation at the end of the game to seal a win . They 're extremely good at what they do and they do it quick and efficiently .

Starter is generally your best guy(s ) , at least in terms of stamina . Ability to go at least 5 - 6 innings routinely is a must . Closer is basically required to throw hard as fuck for one inning , and do so under extreme pressure . Setup / reliever is generally the rest of the guys in your bullpen , those not good enough to be a starter / closer . I 'm sure someone could elaborate .

There are several factors that go into what makes a pitcher suited for each role . But the main factor is usually whether you can cut it as a starter . Most relief pitchers ( closers included ) are actually failed starting pitchers . * Starters are workhorses , and while they throw the most pitches , stamina is n't usually really a " hallmark " trait of starters . Most relievers do n't go to the dugout exhausted after throwing one , 15 - pitch inning . What 's more important for starters is pitch diversity . A starter needs at least three " plus " pitches ( pitches that are better than average ) . This is because a starter will see each batter between two and five times an outing . If you just throw one pitch , hitters will be better able to hone in on that pitch and are less likely to be fooled , especially as a starter wears down in later innings . So they need to have more than pitch to get batters out . By the same token , most starters are n't the fireballers whipping the ball in there at 100 MPH ( though a few guys do throw some heat ) . They ca n't throw with maximum effort each pitch since they 're expected to pitch 5 - 7 innings in most cases . Some starting pitchers are what they call " innings eaters . " These are essentially " just a guy , " in that they 're probably not going to throw 7 scoreless innings while striking out 10 batters , but they can usually get to the 6th inning without surrendering a ton of runs . These pitchers typically have low strikeout totals and less - than - great - but - not - bad ERAs . * Closers are usually a team 's best relief pitcher . They 're typically only asked to work one inning or less , so they can put all their effort into each pitch . As such , many of the games hardest throwers ( such as Aroldis Chapman and Craig Kimbrel ) are closers . Closers typically rely on one pitch ( usually a hard fastball ) to do most of the damage . A closer will usually have another " out " pitch to throw batters off when they 're expecting fastball . That being said , with few exceptions , most closers just get on the mound and fire off fastballs . As for personality , since a closer comes in at the end of games when it 's ( relatively ) close , these are the guys who usually have ice in their veins . They tend to exhibit an aggressive mentality . You do n't want a guy whose confidence is going to get shaken up because he allowed one base runner when the margin is so small . Closers tend to be a dime a dozen , too . Guys who were all - star level closers one year could be out of a job three years later . There are numerous stories of closer who have had one bad postseason whose careers never got back on track -- Mark Woehlers and Jose Mesa immediately come to mind . * Other relievers -- there are a lot of these guys from situational relievers to setup men to middle relievers . Setup men are usually like a closer , they just come into the game in the 8th inning instead of the 9th . A lot of setup men become closers later in their career . Other relievers can be any number of types of pitchers . Perhaps a team is carrying 6 starters on its roster ( the typical rotation is 5 ) , the sixth guy might be used to throw lots of innings when a starter has a bad outing and gets pulled early or used as a spot starter if game days fall in a weird fashion ( such as with doubleheaders ) . Some guys are in the bullpen because they have a funky delivery that works better when you only have to face a batter once before they can adjust to your strange mechanics . This is true of sidearm pitchers . Throwing sidearm also puts a lot of additional strain on your elbows , making it difficult to throw a lot of innings using that type of delivery . About 99 % of starting pitchers throw either overhand or from the 3/4 arm slot . Others are pitchers who are especially proficient at getting either left- or right - handed batters out . Many times a guy who is great against lefties might be atrocious against right - handed hitters and vice versa . These relievers are typically asked to work an inning or less to get out a particular batter . * * tl;dr * * The biggest to keep in mind is that a lot of relief pitchers are starters who could n't develop a second or third pitch or are pitchers with unusual deliveries . Starters are usually guys who have multiple pitches in their arsenal and can get batters out who get several opportunities to see their stuff . Edit : grammar and clarification

question: Zeno 's Paradox of the Tortoise I understand the mathematics behind it , but it does not fit into my head that Aquilles would never reach the tortoise . Is n't this in conflict with Newtonian Kinematics ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: It 's in conflict with the way we actually experience the universe , which proves at least one thing : mathematical proofs are n't everything . There have been various ways proposed to resolve the paradox , including : * space and time are n't inifinitely divisible , but come in tiny " chunks " -- a good candidate for this might be the Planck unit , which is the smallest possible distance in space or time that is possible to measure ; * do n't forget that as the distance between Achilles and the tortoise decreases , so does the time Achilles needs to cover that distance , and at the point where Achilles covers an infinitesimal distance in an infinitesimal amount of time is where Achilles catches up with the tortoise ; * the problem assumes that the sum of any infinite series is infinity , but this is not the case ; here , the sum of the infinite series of ever - decreasing distances between Achilles and the tortoise is not infinity , but the distance Achilles travels to catch up with the tortoise which is finite .

You 've hit on exactly why it is a paradox . Mathematically , every time he closes the distance to the tortoise , it has move a little further , so he will always be behind . But practically , we know that in the real world it is easy to outrun a tortoise . Paradox . But really I 've always found it a little ... contrived . Considering you can just as easily say " He runs at ten mph , the tortoise runs at 0.1MPH , at what time T does his distance equal the tortoise 's distance ... chatgpt_answers: The paradox of the Tortoise and Achilles is a thought experiment that was described by Zeno of Elea, a Greek philosopher who lived in the 5th century BCE. The paradox goes like this: Imagine that there is a race between Achilles, who is the fastest runner, and a tortoise. The tortoise has a small head start, so it is ahead of Achilles when the race starts. However, Achilles is able to run much faster than the tortoise, so he quickly closes the gap between them. Just as Achilles is about to pass the tortoise, the tortoise takes one small step forward. Now, Achilles has to run a little bit more to catch up to the tortoise again. But by the time Achilles catches up, the tortoise has taken another small step forward. This process repeats over and over, and Zeno argued that this means that Achilles could never actually catch the tortoise. The paradox of the Tortoise and Achilles seems to be in conflict with Newtonian kinematics, which is a branch of physics that describes how objects move and change speed. According to Newtonian kinematics, if two objects are moving at constant speeds in the same direction, the faster object will eventually catch up to the slower object. One way to resolve the paradox is to realize that Zeno's argument relies on the idea of infinity, which is a concept that can be difficult to understand. Zeno argued that in order to catch the tortoise, Achilles would have to cover an infinite number of distances, which is impossible. However, we know that in reality, there is no such thing as an infinite number of distances. Instead, there is a finite (or limited) number of distances that can be covered, even if that number is very large. This means that, according to Newtonian kinematics, Achilles should eventually catch the tortoise, even if it takes a very long time.

question: 3G/4G. Basically , how does 3G/4 G work ? Is there just a magical satellite ? I do n't understand and wikipedia hurts my brain so ... Really , please actually explain it like you would to a 5 year old . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: That 's a pretty broad question . I think it 's really 3 questions in one , so I 'll try to tackle each one individually . * * What 's the difference between 2 G , 3 G , and 4 G ? * * Imagine there is a deliver service . At the beginning they have a very basic setup of just a few horses that run on small local roads . It can only deliver a small amount of packages a day because of constraints on the delivery center , the amount you can put on your horses , and the 1 lane roads you 're stuck using . That 's basically 2 G or EDGE service . A few years later after government regulators agree that they 're doing a good job and will help widen the roads and everyone thinks it 's a good time to update the entire delivery centers and buy some trucks . Now everyone have a much larger facility for moving packages / data from point A to point B. There are also new larger trucks that can fit more per load , and the roads are now bigger for everyone to drive more load through . Great ! You 've got 3 G ! 3 G operates pretty fast but soon everyone and their mom want to send packages so the government says ok , we 'll reserve some highway space , some 16 - wheeler trucks , and automated systems in delivery centers to get packages moved as quickly as possible . Now you 're at 4 G speed , you can now move A LOT of data at once . In this analogy the delivery centers are the switch centers at the major telecom companies . To move more data through with each new generation of service ( 2 G , 3 G , 4 G ) the equipment need to be updated . The roads in this are basically spectrum frequency . Which are regulated by the government / FCC . The feds have to sell or free up additional spectrum for telecom companies to operate more data on the higher frequency channels . Trucks are basically the underlying internet backbone that can accommodate for more and faster data transmission . Without all 3 upgrading almost at the same speed , it 's impossible to move from from one generation to the next . Also , your cell phones have to upgrade to the latest generation of processors too because high data - speeds require faster chips to process it . ---------------- * * So how does my cell phone communicate data wirelessly ? * * Think of your phone as a just like a mailbox that you leave a request letter in the morning for Youtube . The delivery guy picks up your letter requesting a large order of videos from Youtube and delivers it to them . In the letter you ask " Please send me a video on XYZ to my address . " When Youtube gets your request via the delivery service , it will package it all up and send you the video as many large packages . Depending on the speed of the delivery centers , size of the trucks , and width of the road the packages can arrive slowly one by one or really fast almost instantaneously . 2 G , 3 G , and 4 G are just different agreed upon standards the service centers , trucks , and roads that are built . The newer generations are faster at delivering packages . Think of your phone as almost like a mailbox . With each new generation of technology , it has to be bigger , stronger , and more automated to support all the packages / data that you 've ordered . If you have an old phone that 's using 2 G , it 's pretty much like a tiny mailbox that the deliver service just says " Nope , it wo n't be able to handle the load . If you want to use our 3 G service , upgrade it so we can fit these larger boxes in . " ------------------ * * How does the data go from your phone to the receiving tower and then get moved to Youtube ? * * Scatter around the entire world are cell phone towers , hundreds of thousands of them . They 're like listening stations that can talk directly with your phone when it 's near . When you turn your cell phone one or walk within range of a new tower , the phone will ask " who 's the closes cell tower ? " A lot of towers will reply by shouting back " Tower XYZ , I 'm here ! " , " Tower ABC , I 'm here . " Depending on how clear your phone hears the response , your phone will start a conversation with one that has the highest quality connection and sounds the clearest . Each cell phone tower is connected to a landline that 's hookup to the internet . Sir Roger Penrose OM FRS HonFInstP (born 8 August 1931) is an English mathematician, mathematical physicist, philosopher of science and Nobel Laureate in Physics. He is Emeritus Rouse Ball Professor of Mathematics in the University of Oxford, an emeritus fellow of Wadham College, Oxford, and an honorary fellow of St John's College, Cambridge and University College London.
Penrose has contributed to the mathematical physics of general relativity and cosmology. human_answers: Hearing other people laugh makes you laugh , too ! Even if it 's fake . You know , if you fake a smile long enough , eventually you become happy ! Try it sometime .
Upvote , I would really like to understand too . I ca n't watch shows that have them ... thank you Modern Family !

A lot of television entertainment as we know it today was carried over from the live theater ( also by way of radio ) , so in a sense , they were theatrical performances that happened to be recorded and broadcast . So in the early days of sitcoms , that 's kind of how they set things up -- each episode would be a little play in front of an audience , who would obviously laugh and react to the action they watched in front of them . The TV audience got used to this format over the decades , so even shows that did n't have a live audience ( animated shows like the Flintstones , single - camera sitcoms like Bewitched ) included an artificial laugh track . And yeah , there is something sort of psychologically comforting about it , our instinctive itch to belong being scratched by laughing along with others , even if the others are on the other side of the screen . I 'm not one of those narrow - minded , cynical types who think that a laugh track is an indicator that the show is somehow cheesy or unsophisticated -- many of television 's most important and genuinely funniest sitcoms have had laugh tracks . Also ridiculous is the assumption that single - camera , non - laugh - track shows are automatically superior -- there've been plenty of stinkers over the years since they 've come into fashion . It 's interesting that someone mentioned " How I Met Your Mother 's " laugh track , because the show is actually a sort of " hybrid " in this sense -- a stylistic choice by its creators , who wanted the feel of the old - fashioned multi - camera sitcoms but wanted to innovate on the format . Unlike Two and a Half Men , The Big Bang Theory and other current " laugh track " sitcoms , who record their shows the old fashioned way by rehearsing through the week and then performing each episode live in front of a studio audience a couple of times ( with the final product being edited together from the two recordings ) , HIMYM actually shoots like a single - camera TV show , without a live audience , shooting the scenes piecemeal and not necessarily in chronological order , and doing as many takes as they feel comfortable with . They do have the cameras and stage set up so that it has the " look " of a traditional sitcom , but it 's put together differently . That allows HIMYM to be paced faster than your average multi - camera sitcom ( a HIMYM episode has about three times as many scenes as a Two and a Half Men episode ) , and allows for a lot of humor " in the edit " via quick flashbacks and cutaways . Because of this and the fact that the laugh track is more subtle ( you do n't hear the audience cheer and whoop it up whenever a beloved character shows up for the first time in the episode ) , some people do n't actually notice that there 's a laugh track until they discover it much later .

question: what is lean manufacturing and who developed
human_answers: Lean manufacturing, lean enterprise, or lean production, often simply, "Lean," is a production practice that considers the expenditure of resources for any goal other than the creation of value for the end customer to be wasteful, and thus a target for elimination.Lean manufacturing is a management philosophy derived mostly from the Toyota Production System (TPS) (hence the term Toyotism is also prevalent) and identified as "Lean" only in the 1990s.
chatgpt_answers:
Lean manufacturing is a production philosophy that emphasizes the minimization of waste and the maximization of value. The goal of lean manufacturing is to create a highly efficient and effective production process that delivers the highest quality products to customers in the shortest time possible, while using the least amount of resources.

Lean manufacturing was developed by Toyota Motor Corporation in the 1950s, based on the principles of the Toyota Production System (TPS). TPS was developed by Taiichi Ohno, who is often referred to as the father of lean manufacturing. The TPS is a manufacturing approach that aims to eliminate waste, reduce variability, and increase efficiency by standardizing work processes and continuously improving them.

Over the years, the principles of lean manufacturing have been adopted by a wide range of industries, including automotive, aerospace, healthcare, and electronics. The concept has also been applied to service industries, such as banking, insurance, and government agencies, to improve efficiency and effectiveness.

Lean manufacturing is a production philosophy that aims to minimize waste and optimize efficiency in the manufacturing process. It was developed by Toyota Motor Corporation in the 1950s and 1960s, and has since been adopted by companies in a variety of industries around the world.

The core principles of lean manufacturing include identifying and eliminating waste (also known as "muda") in the manufacturing process, using just-in-time production to minimize inventory, and empowering workers to identify and solve problems in the production process. These principles are designed to help companies produce high-quality products at a lower cost, while also improving customer satisfaction and responsiveness.

There are many tools and techniques that companies can use to implement lean manufacturing, including value stream mapping, kanban systems, and visual management. By adopting a lean philosophy, companies can improve their efficiency, reduce waste and costs, and increase competitiveness.

Lean manufacturing is a production methodology that aims to minimize waste and maximize efficiency in the manufacturing process. The goal of lean manufacturing is to eliminate activities that do not add value to the product, such as unnecessary transportation, excess inventory, and unnecessary motion. This approach was developed by Toyota Production System (TPS), a system of manufacturing that was developed by the Toyota Motor Corporation in the mid-20th century. TPS is also known as "lean manufacturing" or simply "lean."

The principles of lean manufacturing are based on the idea that value is created through a series of interconnected processes, and that waste can be reduced by identifying and eliminating non-value-adding activities in these processes. Lean manufacturing focuses on continuous improvement, or "kaizen," and encourages the involvement of all employees in the identification and elimination of waste.

Some of the key principles of lean manufacturing include:

Identifying the value that a customer is willing to pay for
Identifying the value stream for each product, including all the steps necessary to create value
Creating flow in the value stream by eliminating waste and reducing variability
Pulling products through the value stream in response to customer demand
Continuously improving the value stream to increase efficiency and reduce waste.
Lean manufacturing has been widely adopted by manufacturers around the world and is considered a key element of the modern manufacturing landscape. It has been credited with helping companies reduce costs, improve quality, and increase competitiveness.

### Lean Manufacturing

**Lean manufacturing**, also known as **lean production**, is a systematic approach to eliminating waste ("muda") with the goal of increasing efficiency, reducing costs, and improving quality. It was developed from the Toyota Production System (TPS), which originated in Japan.

#### Key Principles:
- **Eliminate Waste**: Identify and remove non-value-added activities such as overproduction, waiting time, unnecessary transportation, excess inventory, extra motion, over-processing, defects, and underutilized talent.
- **Value Stream Mapping**: Visualize all steps involved in producing a product or service to identify where value is added and where it isn't.
- **Continuous Improvement**: Implement practices like Kaizen to constantly seek ways to improve processes and eliminate inefficiencies.
- **Respect for People**: Empower employees at every level to contribute ideas and solutions, fostering teamwork and engagement.
- **Pull Systems**: Produce only what is needed by customers, rather than pushing products based on forecasts alone.

#### Origins and Development:
Lean manufacturing evolved from TPS principles introduced around 1948‚Äì1973 during the reigns of Taichi Ohno and later expanded through Shigeo Shingo's expertise. The system was further influenced by others including Kaisuke Usui and Womack & Jones (*The Machine That Changed the World*, 1990). 

It spread globally due to its effectiveness beyond auto manufacturing into various industries, driven largely by books describing Toyota‚Äôs methods.

Self-checkout registers, also known as self-service tills or kiosks, are automated machines that allow customers to scan and pay for their own items without the assistance of a store employee. These registers are commonly used in supermarkets and other retail stores to speed up the checkout process and reduce the need for human labor.

There are several ways that self-checkout registers can prevent fraud without checking ID or requiring a signature. Here are a few examples:

Security cameras: Many self-checkout registers are equipped with security cameras that can record video of the transactions taking place. This can help to deter fraud and can also provide evidence if fraud does occur.

Weight sensors: Some self-checkout registers are equipped with weight sensors that can detect if the weight of the items scanned matches the weight of the items in the shopping cart. This can help to prevent customers from scanning cheaper items and then substituting them with more expensive ones.

Barcode scanners: Self-checkout registers use barcode scanners to read the unique codes on each item. This helps to ensure that the correct price is charged and can also help to prevent fraud by making it more difficult for customers to scan fake or stolen barcodes.

Credit card scanners: When customers pay with a credit card, the self-checkout register will scan the card and check to make sure it is valid. This helps to prevent fraud by ensuring that the card is not stolen or counterfeit.

Overall, self-checkout registers are designed to be secure and reliable, and they use a variety of different technologies to prevent fraud and ensure that transactions are processed correctly.

question: How can the ROE on a stock be more than 100%?
human_answers: A company's Return on Equity (ROE) is its net income divided by its shareholder's equity.  The shareholder's equity is the difference between total assets and total liabilities, and is not dependent on the stock price. What it takes to have a ROE over 100% is to have the income be greater than the equity.  This might happen for a variety of reasons, but one way a high ROE happens is if the shareholder's equity (the divisor) is small, which can occur if past losses have eroded the company's capital (the original invested cash and retained earnings).  If the equity has become a small value, the income for some period might exceed it, and so the ROE would be over 100%. Operating margin is not closely related to ROE.  Although operating income is related to net income, to calculate the margin you divide by sales, which is completely unrelated to shareholder's equity.  So there is no relationship with ROE to be expected.  Operating margin is primarily dependent on market conditions, and can be substantially different in different industries.
chatgpt_answers: It is possible for a company's return on equity (ROE) to be more than 100%. ROE is a measure of the profitability of a company in relation to the equity of its shareholders. It is calculated by dividing the net income of the company by the shareholder equity.There are a few ways that a company's ROE could be more than 100%. One possibility is that the company has a very high net income relative to its shareholder equity. This could be the result of strong financial performance or a low level of equity relative to the size of the company.Another possibility is that the company has negative shareholder equity. In this case, the ROE would be calculated by dividing the net income by a negative number, which would result in a ROE that is greater than 100%. This could occur if the company has accumulated a large amount of debt or if it has incurred significant losses in the past.It is important to note that a high ROE does not necessarily indicate that a company is a good investment. There are many factors that can affect a company's financial performance and ROE, and it is important to consider a range of financial metrics when evaluating an investment.

  - This results in a **higher ROE**.

question: Asperger 's Syndrome What separates it from full blown autism , where do you draw the line between bad at social interaction and being diagnosed with it , etc . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: As someone with Asperger 's , the best way I can explain it is I have to consciously decide to do most actions that appear to be innate to others communicating ( eye contact , facial expressions , changing tone , etc ) . I think this is different from being " just bad " at socializing because when I observe people that appear to be morons , it still looks like their actions come naturally . I 'm trying to explain in more detail , but the scope of what I 've observed relating to why my social interactions go poorly so consistently is large , to the point where a broad explanation would be too verbose , so I gave up typing it . If you have a specific question I can answer it .

The term " autism " is less a diagnosis in the sense of " You have chicken pox , " and more a diagnosis in the sense of " You have some red itchy bumps . " Of course it 's more scientific than that , but what I 'm getting at is that it 's important to understand that it comes in a wide range ( or " spectrum " ) of severities and forms . As /u / Vexal mentions , one of the biggest " symptoms " of the autism spectrum disorders is an inability of one 's brain to handle certain things " automatically " . Say you 're " on the spectrum " . If it 's hot out , it may not occur to you to take your jacket off ( such would be an automatic thought process ) . Or if you put something down , it may not occur to you to put it where it 's " supposed " to go ( e.g. books go on shelves , plates go in the sink ) . Or if it 's bright outside , your brain may not automatically " dim " your sense of sight so you 're not overwhelmed . There are many different sides to the spectrum , but they mostly revolve around having to use conscious thought to take care of things that most people 's brains simply handle for you ( like reminding you to bring your backpack when you leave for school ) . In terms of severity , some ( like my girlfriend ) are high - functioning enough to be thought of as a bit peculiar / goofy but " mostly normal " by those unaware of what autism is . Still , there are others that have extreme difficulties with communication , sensory integration , and societal norms to the point of being almost entirely isolated from " normal " culture / community . Both are equally " autism " though ( despite their difference in severity ) , so " full blown " may be a bit misleading . The terms " Asperger 's " and " autism " have relatively little to do with severity . That said , " Asperger 's Syndrome " is no longer considered a separate clinical diagnosis by the newest version of the be - all - end - all book of mental disorder diagnosis ( the DMS-5 ) . So in truth , as of 2013 , Asperger 's is not really a thing anymore . Now it 's a part of the " autism spectrum disorders " . Think of this distinction like the flu viruses . There are actually a large number of variants , each with minor differences in mortality , transmission , etc . But from a layman 's perspective , they 're almost all basically the same . A particularly strong strain , like H1N1 , might be treated differently , but we as patients certainly do n't keep track of the many many seasonal flu viruses that go around . It 's the same with " autism " , " savant " , and " Asperger 's " . The term " savant " encompasses a particularly unique kind of " autism " ( much as " H1N1 " is a particularly unique strain of influenza ) , and so it 's useful diagnostically . But the old criteria for " Asperger 's " are not so unique as to warrant a separate diagnosis in contrast to the other extremely similar manifestations of " autism " ( just as seasonal flu viruses are all lumped together ) . With regards to your last question about the difference between autism and just being a poor communicator / socializer , remember that diagnoses are much more about * cause * and * kind * than * severity * . It 's not the severity that matters for labeling disorders , but the specific ways in which function is different . Take autism 's common problems with verbal communication . In autism , it has a lot to do with being unable to decide whether a word is an appropriate / accurate match for a thought or feeling . This is a separate disorder from expressive aphasia , where patients can successfully use individual words but have difficulty assembling them into fluid sentences , leading to " caveman - speech " ( " Eat food good good " ) . Fluent aphasia ( yet another disorder leading to " poor communication " ) affects the patient by preserving " speech " ( i.e. reasonable sounding words and sentences ) but impairing the rules of " language " ( i.e. messing up grammar , confusing words or intonation ) leading to nonsense . In all cases , it 's important to know the specific ways in which communication is impaired and how they 're different . So psychologists divide common patterns of unusual function into meaningful groups , and autism is just one such cluster of unusual mental symptoms that seem to occur together a statistically significant amount of the time . If you yourself are bad at communicating for one or two individual reasons that do n't seem to match any large population , then there 's no real reason to give it a name . But if 1 in 50 children born in the U.S. go on to later have the exact same cluster of insurmountable problems with communication , then there may be a common cause , in which case a formal name and diagnosis criteria can be clinically useful .

Autism is a spectrum disorder , meaning that there are varying levels of severity ranging from high functioning to needing quite a bit of help . Aspergers is a particular diagnosis on this spectrum typically on the higher functioning end . So essentially they are under the same catch - all because we do n't really know what causes either disorders . Hope this helps . Edit : extra " the "

However, they usually have normal to above-normal intelligence and do not have the significant delays in language development that are often seen in other forms of autism.

The main difference between Asperger's syndrome and "full-blown" autism is the severity of the symptoms. People with Asperger's syndrome often have fewer and milder symptoms than those with other forms of autism.

A healthcare professional, such as a doctor or psychologist, can determine whether someone meets the criteria for a diagnosis of Asperger's syndrome or another form of autism after evaluating their symptoms and behavior.

question: Please explain what is "Heuristic (computer science)"
human_answers:
In mathematical optimization and computer science, heuristic (from Greek Œµ·ΩëœÅŒØœÉŒ∫œâ "I find, discover") is a technique designed for solving a problem more quickly when classic methods are too slow for finding an approximate solution, or when classic methods fail to find any exact solution.  This is achieved by trading optimality, completeness, accuracy, or precision for speed.  In a way, it can be considered a shortcut.
A heuristic function, also simply called a heuristic, is a function that ranks alternatives in search algorithms at each branching step based on available information to decide which branch to follow. For example, it may approximate the exact solution.
chatgpt_answers:
In computer science, a heuristic is a technique that allows a computer program to find a solution to a problem more quickly than would be possible using an algorithm that guarantees a correct solution. Heuristics are often used when an exact solution is not necessary or when it is not feasible to find an exact solution because of the amount of time or resources it would require.



Heuristics are typically used to solve optimization problems, where the goal is to find the best solution out of a set of possible solutions. For example, in the traveling salesman problem, the goal is to find the shortest route that visits a set of cities and returns to the starting city. An algorithm that guarantees a correct solution to this problem would be very slow, so heuristics are often used instead to quickly find a solution that is close to the optimal one.



Heuristics can be very effective, but they are not guaranteed to find the optimal solution, and the quality of the solution they find may vary depending on the specific problem and the heuristic used. As a result, it is important to carefully evaluate the quality of the solutions found by a heuristic and to consider whether an exact solution is necessary in a particular context.
qwen_answers:
efers to a method or approach used in problem-solving, particularly in **artificial intelligence (AI)** and **algorithm design**, where the goal is to find a **satisfactory solution** rather than an **optimal one**. Heuristics are often based on **rules of thumb**, **experience**, or **approximations** that help guide the search for a solution more efficiently.

---

## ‚úÖ Key Characteristics of Heuristics:

1. **Not Perfect**: Heuristics do not always guarantee finding the best solution.
2. **Efficient**: They aim to reduce the computational effort needed to reach a solution.
3. **Practical**: Often used when the exact solution would be too time-consuming or impossible to compute.
4. **Adaptive**: May vary depending on the specific problem or environment.

---

## üß† Why Use Heuristics?

- **Complex Problems**: For problems with a large search space, like pathfinding, scheduling, or puzzle solving, exhaustive search is impractical.
- **Time Constraints**: When you need a good enough answer quickly, heuristics can provide results faster than exact methods.
- **Uncertainty**: In situations where perfect information is unavailable, heuristics can make informed guesses.

---

question: Car sickness ? What is car sickness / motion sickness and why do i get it ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Ok , this is the explanation I got from my doctor when I actually was 5 , so take it with a grain of salt . Basically , the brain gets signals from the rest of your body about your movement . My eyes know that I am moving , but the rest of me thinks that I am still because I am just sitting there . This confuses the brain , and makes it feel icky . However , I ca n't explain why , if that is how it actually works , closing my eyes makes it worse rather then better .

It is because the inner ear tells the body when it is banked and when it is moving . When you are in a car or a boat your eyes are telling your brain that you are not moving while your ears are telling you that you are . The more sensitive your inner ear is to movement the more sick you feel . This is why it varies from person to person

ELI5 Answer : Your eyes are telling your brain that you 're not moving ( because the car around you is n't ) and your body is telling your brain that you are moving ( because it feels the movement ) . In a car , sitting in the front usually helps . ELI10 Answer : [ What bob1753 said . ] ( URL_0 ) . Your inner ear has three loops filled with fluid . This fluid moves with your head and tells your brain how you are oriented with respect to gravity and - like holding a glass of water while riding a bike - this fluid moves when you yourself move , and it tells your brain that you 're moving . Your eyes are sending back signals of a completely stagnant environment - car seats , dashboard , and so on , with everything outside the car appearing to the eyes to be moving . So your eyes think that it 's the world around you that 's flying by , not that you 're in a car . This conflict makes you nauseous . It 's also why people with inner ear infections and inner ear trauma sometimes have problems balancing . If those loops are damaged , the head does n't know where it is in respect to gravity , and the rest of the body ca n't use it as a guide , and so the person has no idea when they 're about to tip over .

Close your eyes and take deep breaths to help calm your stomach
Chew gum or suck on a hard candy to help your ears "pop"

question: Evidence for/against negative correlation between commodity futures, stocks
human_answers: The correlation I heard most about in economics/finance was that stock prices and bond yields were negatively correlated; as the stock market does better, bond yields fall (company's doing well as evidenced by stocks, so it's a good credit risk, so YTM of its bonds on the market goes down). The correlation, if any, between the stock and futures market should be visible in the actual price histories. Index prices may be useful, but what's more likely is that various future prices have correlation with various companies' stocks. Where the future reflects the price of a raw material that is a significant cost of goods sold for a company, you'll see these two move inversely to each other in the short term. I think that if there is a causative relationship here, its that futures prices influence stock prices, not the other way around. The futures market generally represents the cost side of a consumer goods producer's bottom line. The stock market represents its profits. As futures go up, profit expectations go down, putting pressure on stock prices. Industries that deal in services, or in other types of goods, can still be affected because a rise in the cost of something consumers need will cause them to spend less on other things which affects margins in those other areas. So, in the short and medium term, when the futures market goes up the stock market sees a dip, and vice versa.  However, companies adapt; they can put upward pressure on prices for their goods to restore their desired margins, usually by slowly increasing them to prevent sticker shock (though elasticity of demand plays a part; the more we need something no matter what it costs, the faster prices can increase). To maintain costs, they can make things cheaper using less expensive materials (more plastic, less steel). They can restructure production processes (translated: move factories offshore, or at least to "right-to-work" states with less union strength) to save costs elsewhere. All of these reduce costs and thus increase profits, but take time to implement. Many of these things reduce direct costs, reducing demand for the commodity and causing the futures prices to go back down. So, over the long term, these differences even out, and it's down to the things that affect the entire market (inflation, consumer/investor confidence, monetary policy).

question: What is the process of publishing a scientific paper ? Why is it talked about as an achievement ? If I make an experiment and write down my results can I not publish them on my own blog ? Why ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Scientific papers are peer reviewed . Journals usually send their drafts for review to 3 - 4 other phds in the field , as well as their own editor . Those people are basically paid to find things that are wrong with your work , and the more prestigious the journal , the harder the scrutiny is .

* * Why is it an achievement :* * " Getting published " , as we call it , is an achievement for researchers and professors because it 's one of the basic principles that helps advance science : sharing your work . Experiments need to be repeatable and replicable for it to be considered scientific knowledge , oftentimes things need to be observed multiple times within a variety of conditions for us to start piecing together what 's actually going on . Peer review methods are employed to maintain standards of quality , improve performance , and provide credibility . When something is peer - reviewed by a journal ( and other experts in the field ) this is a way of making sure that the process was sound . They also check for possible experimental errors or over extensions of facts . The short story being that " experts in your field " ( several phd holders and other researchers ) have read your study and have found it worthwhile enough to be shared with the masses . Not only is this validation rewarding ( you 're moving science along ! ! ) , but oftentimes your academic institution pays you good money to have their school 's " prestigious name " produce the findings . Having more peer - reviewed articles , in academia , usually means you 're more knowledgeable on a certain topic . Being more knowledgeable leads to higher employment positions , fame , and even better pay . * * tldr :* * more peer - reviewed articles = more scrutiny = more experience = more " knowledge / expertise " = more influence = MORE MONEY . _ _ _ _ * * Why ca n't I publish them on my own blog ? * * Well , you can do an experiment , write down the results and publish it on your blog . But it 's practically meaningless until other people replicate your findings . Likewise : 1 ) Unless you 're a credible researcher ( with a degree / research experience / etc ) then people will assume your methodology and findings are flawed until you have evidence that you did do the experiment . Even if you did do an experiment and have numbers , we have no way of knowing if you conducted the experiment scientifically . When people work in academia , they are usually working in conjunction with other professionals who can ensure / oversee the experiment 's testing . One thing that is detrimental to science is the fabrication of numbers , results , and conclusions ‚Äì this is all prevented via the peer - review process . 2 ) You can publish anything on a personal blog , however the studies published in scientific journals have at least been checked by researchers and experts in the field . * * tldr :* * personal blogs are not scrutinized and are not regarded as outlets for scientific experiments / facts by the community as a whole . _ _ _ Source : I 've spent time working in a research lab at a large public university , sorry this was a long comment but I wanted to make sure I included enough .

The usual process is : 1 ) Publication has a call for papers across one or ( more commonly ) a variety of subject areas selected by their editors , usually important current / future research areas . Researchers will typically keep on top of the various calls for papers in areas they are working . 2 ) Researchers with appropriate information to publish submit an abstract or draft paper containing a summary of their work . The process can vary , but it will result in final papers being down selected by editors and provided to peer reviewers with appropriate expertise . 3 ) Reviewers will be provided with the prospective paper for review . They will either not recommend the paper , recommend with edits , or recommend as - is . It is the editors job to aggregate that information and make a final decision . In my field ( wireless communications ) recommend with edits is extremely common as papers originating from Asia are common , often high quality , and almost always never reviewed by a proper english technical editor prior to first submission . This process can go several rounds . 4 ) Accepted papers are published and are now usually property of the publisher ( you can not re - publish somewhere else ) with the authors retaining rights of use . As to why it is viewed as an achievement ? This process is long , and for prestigious outlets , competitive . It is also a very tangible , non - temporal professional achievement . Jobs come and go , people get promoted and 're - assigned ' , but you have that publication forever ( barring extenuating circumstances ) . It 's also a very real way for people to make a wide impact to their field , both through advancement , and the education of others . Presenting a paper at a conference provides the opportunity to positively impact the professional life of * many * other people , and it can be very rewarding . You can absolutely publish your own experiments on your blog ! And if technical publishing is an area of interest , you should strive to better your technical writing through practice and feedback . Unfortunately , your blog is not a peer reviewed publication and probably has no scientific credibility . This is n't a bad thing , despite sounding harsh ; it 's just the way it is . Everyone starts somewhere , and spreading knowledge is awesome so go for it !

question: Why do electronics stop working after they are submerged by water ? I could understand if they have power running through them , but what about electronics that are powered off completely ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: The immediate answer is conductivity . Water is extremely conductive to electricity . If water is connecting two electrical components , electricity will flow between them . If it 's connecting two components that are n't designed to connect , that causes errors or possibly even permenant damage . Water can also permenantly damage some electronic parts on a physical level , like screens , batteries , buttons , etc . If something is n't designed to be completely submerged in water , it probably wo n't work again until it 's dried . Even then , residual moisuture can cause malfunctions . Speakers are a good example : water in between the diaphram and the casing can cause it to lose the ability to transmit sound clearly . If you 've dunked your phone in water , you might be able to see moisuture droplets beneath the lens of the camera , ruining photos more or less permenantly . Water also causes quick corrosion to ferrous metals , causing those components to wear out or lose their conductivity .

A few thoughts ... Water is conductive , so even if the device is powered off , where water bridges the contacts of the battery and connects it to other places on the circuit , you can now be potentially dumping a whole batteries worth of power into small components that can not handle it . Even without a battery , it also does n't mean the circuit is safe however , as components like capacitors can hold an electrical charge for significant lengths of time , and again if that current gets to the wrong point there can be serious damage . Water can also damage some components by just being there - components that rely on precision spacing , movement or contact ( thing the layers of a touch screen maybe , or the moving parts of an accelerometer ) can be damaged if a physical item breaches this . Water is also corrosive to metals , and due to the tiny sizes of components and circuit board traces used in consumer electronics , this can take hold quickly and destructively . A protected ( painted ) steel beam may take decades to rust to the point of worry , but a tiny trace a fraction of a millimeter thick wo n't last long . Water is also rarely pure , but comes with a wide and varied collection of other materials dissolved in it - an obvious one being saltwater , which is hugely corrosive ( far more than pure water ) and will dry out leaving deposits of salt behind , which will continue to corrode and damage the circuitry .
If they are powered off and you get them out quickly and let them dry completely , they will often be fine . But drying them out completely is n't trivial .
chatgpt_answers:

Even if the device is powered off, the water can still get inside and cause damage. For example, the water can corrode or rust the metal components inside the device, which can make it stop working properly.

So, to sum it up, electronics can stop working after they are submerged in water because the water can cause a short circuit or damage the internal components.

human_answers: There 's certain words that have different meanings to chemists than they do in common usage . In normal usage " sugar " refers to table sugar but to a chemist it can refer to a family of chemicals - sucrose , fructose , lactose , and a few others . " Salt " is the same - table salt is sodium chloride but the generic term can refer to any chemical with a similar structure . " Alcohol " is used the same way . The stuff that people drink is called " ethyl alcohol " . Rubbing alcohol is made of of similar chemicals like methyl or isopropyl alcohol - they act like drinking alcohol for things like cleaning cuts but if you drink them they 'll make you really sick .

" Alcohol " actually refers to a * group * of chemicals . Drinkable alcohol is ethanol , while rubbing alcohol can be either ethanol or isopropanol . Even when rubbing alcohol is ethanol , though , it 's allowed ( and in some cases , legally required ) to have other things that are unsafe to drink in it .

Rubbing alcohol is denatured so that it is unsafe to drink . Methanol is often added and is toxic to the body ( it can cause blindness - hence the phrase " blind drunk . " ) Isopropyl alcohol is converted into acetone in the liver . Adding either methanol ( methyl alcohol ) or isopropyl alcohol makes the rubbing alcohol toxic .

question: Hard Drives What is the difference between SAS and SATA Hard Drives ? Why do they come in two sizes ? 2.5 " and 3.5 " Can you properly explain what the cache on a Hard Drive does ? What is a hybrid Hard Drive ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: SAS and SATA are serial versions of SCSI and ATA . SAS and SATA provide better speed and some additional capabilities over their predecessors . SAS , and SCSI before it , have been typically used in servers and high - end workstations . ATA and SATA are typically used in lower - end applications . These days , think of SAS as fast as enough for multiple users ( hence servers ) and SATA as fast enough for one single user ( hence laptops , desktops ) . The lines blur a little in some applications ( like large SAN units with dozens of SATA drives ) , but this is ELI5 . Th different form factors are for different applications . Smaller drives fit smaller machines but usually cost more . 2.5 are usually used in laptops or in blade servers , which are very compact high - performance machines . Cache is a bit of actual memory , which is a lot , a LOT faster than the HD itself . There are many ways to use cache , but typically , when your computer tells your hard drive to read a chunk of data , it reads that chunk plus the next few chunks and puts the whole thing in cache . It is very likely that sequential chunks will be required by the computer , so that when it asks for the next one , it is already in the cache and can be delivered much faster . To understand a hybrid disk , you need to understand SSDs . SSDs are solid state drives , they are a quantity of actual memory that presents itself to a system as if it were a disk . They are a lot faster than traditional HDs , but they are a lot more expensive . Enter the hybrid drive : it has a large conventional hard drive and a small SSD inside the same unit . This can be seen by your system as two different drives , one very fast and small , the other slow but large . Some systems can use the SSD portion of a hybrid drive as cache , but in this case a lot larger than your typical cache . It works as before , trying to read ahead what you might need next , but also making writes faster : when you save something , it saves to the SSD portion , and from your point of view the operation is over . Then the drive copies the data from the SSD to the HD , which is slow but does n't affect you . This gives you the " feeling " that you have a very large , very fast drive .

SAS and SATA are just two interfaces ( ways to connect hard drives . ) They come in several sizes ( also 1.8 " ) because some devices are only large enough for smaller sizes , while larger sizes offer more performance and capacity . 2.5 " is the size that fits most laptops , while 3.5 " is typical for desktops . The cache is used to quickly retrieve often - used data . This data is stored in RAM , which is much faster to access than the actual platters of the hard drive . A hybrid hard drive is a device combining a SSD ( a much faster and non - mechanical , but more expensive per MB successor to the hard drive ) and a traditional hard drive .

chatgpt_answers: SAS (Serial Attached SCSI) and SATA (Serial Advanced Technology Attachment) are types of hard drives that are used to store data. SAS hard drives are generally faster and more expensive than SATA hard drives. The size of a hard drive refers to the size of the physical drive itself. A 2.5-inch hard drive is smaller and thinner than a 3.5-inch hard drive. The size of the hard drive does not affect its performance. The cache on a hard drive is like a small amount of memory that is used to store frequently accessed data. When you access a file on your hard drive, it is stored in the cache so that it can be retrieved more quickly the next time you need it. This helps to speed up the performance of your computer. A hybrid hard drive is a type of hard drive that combines a traditional hard drive with a small amount of solid-state storage. The solid-state storage acts as a cache, similar to the cache on a regular hard drive, but it is faster and can store more data. This allows a hybrid hard drive to improve the performance of your computer.

But wait‚Äîbanks aren‚Äôt keeping all those dollars under their mattresses (they used to sometimes, but now they‚Äôre digital!). Most big banks loan out money too. Like, if someone wants a new bike or even wants to buy a house someday, they can borrow from the bank. The bank charges a little bit more than what they give as interest on the savings account. That difference is like the price for borrowing‚Äîyou‚Äôre paying a fee so the bank doesn‚Äôt lose anything.

Plus, there are fees. Think of them as small tips or charges for services:
- If Mom uses her debit card to pay for groceries, she just spends her own money.
- But if she writes a check and needs help cashing it, maybe the bank charges a few cents or dollars?
- Or if Dad forgets his password and calls customer service, maybe he‚Äôll get a charge for that time?

And then, big banks connect lots of people who want to save and lots of people who need loans. By matching these two groups, the bank becomes an expert matchmaker, charging everyone a tiny bit to use its service.

human_answers: Memory locations in a computer are accessed by their address . This address is just a number : you can think of them like individual street numbers on a VERY long street . Sometimes different programs or parts of a program need to use the same data . Instead of sending all the data , it is easier just to send the address where the data starts instead . This is known as a pointer . So a pointer is just an address ( memory index ) telling you where the data starts . It points to the data . If methods or programs are sharing data using pointers , then they are really accessing exactly the same data in the same memory location . If one program or method changes this data , the other program can now only read the new data . The old data is lost ( it has been overwritten ) to both programs . EDIT : This is just an example of pointer use . They have many other uses including indexing data , linked lists , program counters , stack pointers , etc .

So Scruffy wrote down the location of the walnut and gave * that * to crackWalnut ( ) ( the scrap of paper he wrote on was duplicated like always ) , who would then go dig it up , crack it , and bury it again .

question: Why do computers get slow ? And how can I prevent it ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: It can vary from computer to computer , but its usually a combination of a few things : * Startup processes - the more you install over time , the more that runs in the background * Wear and tear - over time you may lose performance as the hardware itself ages , especially with hard drives * malware - bad software is bad , and will cause a lot of problems over time * Driver issues - drivers are instructions for your computer . Out of date drivers can cause your computer to be pretty inefficient . A simple analogy is this : You start out a lean , fast , runner . Over time , you start adding things to your running regiment . As you add things , it takes you a little longer to get out the front door . You get out eventually , but maybe it takes you 1 minute instead of 15 seconds . Since you 've got these other things on your mind , when you try to do things while juggling , sometimes it takes you a while . Normally you can run and wave to the neighbor within 30 seconds of leaving the door , but now you have that morning weather software and the news software that slow you down a bit , so you do n't get a chance to wave until about a minute out the door instead . You try cleaning up your regiment with some new techniques(new drivers ) so that you do your regiment more efficiently , and that helps a little bit here and there . Some regiments run better thanks to your new techniques , others are n't effected - some might even be worse than before . But you take what you can get . One day you end up getting sick from a virus , and * everything * goes to crap . Your running slows down , you have a hard time trying to wave to the neighbors , and some days you ca n't get out the front door . At that point , sometimes starting fresh can help - you strip yourself back down to your basic new - runner state , ( reformatting ) , and go from there . But its been a while - your joints might not be as good ( hardware getting older ) , so maybe you need 30 seconds instead of 15 . Still better than where you were though !

People like /u / lumpy_potato have covered the " why " . I 'm going to talk more about how to prevent it . * * * Stop installing crap you do n't need * * . Do n't install trial games , toolbars , " accelerators " , video players recommended by websites or anything else that looks interesting . Only install what you need . * Uninstall all of the useless crap that you installed before you started following the first step . In general , if it 's not made by Microsoft , it 's not a hardware driver , or it 's not software that you use regularly , get rid of it . * Bring in * reputable * Software help . Run malwarebytes or ccleaner to check for malware . Do n't run anything that 's advertised to you . * Make backups . This is a good idea in general , but I mention it here because , if you have backups , you can painlessly ... * Reinstall . After enough installs , uninstalls , and upgrades , there will be enough bits of junk left on your disk and in your registries that starting over might be your best bet . One idea that I like : create an account with admin rights and an account without . Use the account without admin rights for day to day work . Only use the admin account when you have to install or upgrade things . ( No web browsing while you 're doing this ! ) That keeps most malware from installing and forces you to stop and think about whether you really need to install the software in question .
As time goes on , you install things on your computer that require more and more resources . Heavier payload = slower speed .

question: How do " Push Notifications " work How is it I am able to get a notification from any one of the apps on my phone at any time even when the app is closed ? Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: There are a few ways a push notification can work . Firstly , they can really be pull notifications in disguise . A background service regularly checks a server to see whether a notification is ready to be ' pushed ' to a program on the phone . Maybe the background service maintains an open TCP connection to the server , sending and receiving data often enough to prevent the connection being closed . ( this seems to be the Google Cloud Messaging method ) The best option is for the remote server to know the IP address of the client , and send messages to that address . But that is harder than it needs to be - there is usually one or more NAT routers and/or firewalls between the internet and most devices preventing this sort of access . This means that they need to do things like UDP tunnelling to achieve this , and UDP tunnelling needs regular keep - alive messages . Thankfully , that is all hidden from programmers and users needing to use push - notifications . As far as they are concerned , the server pushes a notification to the phone , and the phone opens the app to retrieve the details .

Generally speaking you " request " things in programming or when working with a computer for that matter . For example when you search for something on google you are making a request for some results . This way of thinking is pervasive in computing . Especially on the internet . Programmers call this process the request / response lifecycle . When a traditional app needs more information , for example , do you a have a new email waiting for you ? The app will run this tried and true cycle of requesting from the server your mail status and telling you based in the response . Push notifications switch the model upside down . With the push model your app registers with the sever and anytime you have new mail it just tells you . It does this by pushing the information your way . Understanding the nuance between the two models is a good chunk if application architecture . Ciao !

The push notification systems rely on some assistance from Google or Apple . Apps can register themselves to receive push notifications , which will be received by your phone 's OS and passed along to the app ( waking it up ) when received . Apple / Google provide a way for developers to give them a small push - message which they pass along to your phone .
chatgpt_answers: Push notifications are a way for apps to send you updates and information, even when the app is not open on your phone. Here's how it works: 1. The app developer creates a notification server that can send messages to the app. 2. When you install the app on your phone, the app asks for your permission to send you push notifications. If you agree, your phone will send a special token to the app's notification server. 3. When the app developer wants to send you a notification, they send a message to the notification server. The server then sends the notification to your phone, along with the special token. 4. Your phone's operating system sees the special token and knows to send the notification to the app. 5. The app receives the notification and displays it on your phone, even if the app is not currently open. That's how push notifications work! Do you have any more questions?
