question: How can things like speed of light and gravity be considered universal constants ? I see how gravity is different for an astronaut then me on Earth , so to say its constant , would n't you have to do experiments on another planet ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Gravity is n't constant . The gravitational constant is a constant . It tells you how much two points of certain mass , certain distance away , pull each other towards themselves . Earth is a big mass , we are a small mass . The amount Earth pulls us towards it could be calculated from this constant . Speed of light being a constant is actually fairly surprising . It seems like , if you traveled fast in one direction , and looked at a ray of light , the light should travel slightly slower or faster from your perspective , than if you were still . Turns out , universe does n't work like that . No matter who you are and where you 're going and how fast , if you check how fast light is going , you always get the exact same speed . Reasons for this are quite complex , I do n't feel confident explaining that part .

> would n't you have to do experiments on another planet ? well , effectively we can do this . Orbiting moons are held in place by gravity , you can take how fast the moon is orbiting verses how close it is to the planet in question , and get an exact coefficient for how hard the pull of gravity is on that object . It just so happens that every time we test this it comes out to exactly what we expect the answer to be given our understanding of how gravity works

You do n't need to do experiments on a distant planet to measure G , the gravitational constant there . It 's easier to look at the path that distant objects take around their galaxy center . From that you can measure the average G in that galaxy . Whenever we do this , we get the same answer 6.67408(31 ) x 10 ^ -11 m^3 / kg‚Ä¢sec^2

Even though the strength of gravity might feel different for an astronaut than it does for you on Earth, that's because the astronaut is much farther away from the center of the Earth than you are. The strength of gravity decreases as you get farther away from the center of a massive object, like a planet. So, an astronaut on the International Space Station, which is about 250 miles above the Earth's surface, feels a slightly weaker force of gravity than you do on the ground. But the universal constant for gravity, which is the strength of gravity at the surface of the Earth, is still the same no matter where you are in the universe.

In order to confirm that these constants are truly universal, scientists have conducted experiments on different planets and in different parts of the universe. They have also used math and physics to make predictions about how these constants should behave in different situations, and then tested those predictions through experiments. Overall, the results of these experiments and predictions have consistently shown that the speed of light and the strength of gravity are the same everywhere in the universe.

The reason why Einstein formulated his theory was because he wanted a way to reconcile two fundamental observations that could not be reconciled by classical physics:
1) The second postulate of special relativity states that all inertial reference frames are equivalent, in other words there exists no unique "absolute" frame from which we observe the world.
2) Maxwell's equations describe the electromagnetic field as propagating at the universal speed limit (the speed of light).
These two observations seemed to contradict each other! In particular, if both of them were true, it follows that if some event happened 1000 miles away then regardless of what kind of spaceship you were traveling in, you would still see those same events happen after 3 seconds had elapsed since their occurrence - i.e., nothing can travel faster than c; which contradicts observation #1 (because your own ship isn't moving through space with respect to itself).
Einstein solved this problem by proposing a new theory of physics called "special relativity". According to this theory, time passes differently depending upon how quickly you're moving relative to other objects around you--and likewise space expands/contracts accordingly too. So instead of being able to measure distance or duration between two points using just one set of units (e.g., meters), now we need three separate sets: Meters, Seconds, and Light Years! This means that when someone says they want something measured "in terms of meters", really what they mean is "...in terms of meter-second-lightyear combinations..."
In other words: There isn't anything particularly magical about these values except for our tendency towards treating them as such--but ultimately everything has some inherent unitless value behind it which determines how much something changes based off

question: What makes it foggy in the morning ? Need answer for my actual 5 yr old . I could n't provide a very good answer for my daughter this morning . Any help is appreciated . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Basically , " fog " is what happens when there 's more moisture in the air than the air can contain while remaining transparent , i.e. , there 's enough moisture in the air to push the humidity level beyond 100 % . That 's not possible , so the excess water appears as fog or condenses as dew / frost . The reason there 's fog in the morning which commonly " burns off " by mid - day is that cold air can hold less moisture than warm air , i.e. , it will take less water to reach 100 % humidity . So given a fixed amount of water in the air , you 'll start to see dew and even fog as the temperature drops , both of which will go away as the temperature rises .

You get fog when you get the right temperature , pressure , and humidity conditions . Here 's a neat experiment you can do to make your own cloud . I 've entertained kids ages 5 - 18 with this trick ( older kids , I substitute rubbing alcohol for the water , and set it on fire ): Get a 5 gallon water bottle ( the kind that goes on a cooler ) that 's empty . Put an ounce or so of water in the bottle and swish it around . Drop a lit match ( or any other source of particulate smoke ) into the bottle . Let it go out . Put your mouth over the opening of the jug , and breathe into the jug , followed by forcing mouthfuls of air into the jug until you ca n't build up any more pressure . Pull your face away , and > poof ! < insta - cloud ! When moist air is under high pressure , a lowering of pressure will result in cloud formation . If you increase the pressure again , the cloud will slowly disappear . If you do it with isopropyl alcohol instead of water , you 'll have a nifty ( and fairly safe ) fuel - air mixture in the jug . Drop a second lit match in , and you can watch the mixture ignite . It also makes a cool hooting noise as it burns .

Take a dry sponge . That is the dry atmosphere . Start adding water slowly , eventually it will be saturated and water will drop off it . This is fog or rain . But the amount of water the air can hold is also controlled by the temperature ( and pressure , but let 's ignore that for simplicity ) . So , once the sponge stops dripping , squeeze it to show the drop in temperature during the night . It should start dripping again since squeezing he sponge allows less water to be absorbed . Even though the air seemed dry in the evening there was still water in the air . As it cools the water in the air will be squeezed out like the sponge in the form of fog and dew . Now let go of the sponge and you will be able to reabsorb all of the water you just squeezed out . This is what happens once the sun comes out and heats up the atmosphere allowing for more water to be evaporated and stored in the warmer air .

question: What do 0 sugar/ 0 calories do to your body ? Currently drinking a 0 calorie + 0 sugar monster . Curious if this just as unhealthy as regular monsters or not . Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: This question is vague . The primary different between sugar free drinks and regular drinks is artificial sweeteners . Unhealthy is pretty relative , caffeine in and of itself is n't " bad " for you , and certain intakes of caffeine ( namely coffee and tea ) have been shown to be good for you . This probably is n't the caffeine , which was developed by plants as a poison to deter predation . The primary artificial sweetener in many drinks is aspartame , which is one of the most widely studied substances on the planet . There has been no conclusive evidence that it is bad for you . It 's not a carcinogen and the argument that it is turned into formaldehyde in your body is invalid because it 's less than physiological levels of formaldehyde you produce daily . There are some arguments as well that it can affect insulin sensitivity and metabolism , but again this is n't really substantiated . Other artificial sweeteners like sucralose and stevia are newer and as a result have less studies , I remember people saying sucralose ( splenda ) caused organomegaly ( swollen internal organs , namely the spleen ) which was years ago and I 've not heard anything since about it . Aspartame specifically is n't " 0 calorie " it is just much much sweeter than sugar so smaller amounts add a comparable amount of " sweetness " , which are effectively 0 calories . For the most part , sugar free options are not any less healthy for you but everything should be in moderation and based on your individual health . If you 're overweight and like energy drinks , you should stick to sugar free . If you 're concerned about the possible effects of artificial sweeteners , and can afford the calories , maybe stick to the real thing .

When something is labeled ' 0 calorie ' , it may have more than 0 calories . In the US , if something has less than 5 calories per serving , the FDA permits them to round - down to 0 . Likewise , if something has less than 0.5 grams of sugar per serving , they are allowed to round that down to 0 . So , it might be better to label it " 0 - ish calories + 0 - ish sugar " - it probably has a tiny bit of both . That said , there 's still a lot of things in that drink . Since there 's effectively no calories , you are n't getting any actual energy in it . In every 8 oz of the drink you get about as much caffeine as two cups of coffee , 100 % of your RDA of vitamins B6 and B12 , a bunch of salt , and a whole bunch of other things like inositol , L - carnitine , L - tartarate , ginseng extract , guarana seed extract , taurine , etc . some of which are mild stimulants , and all of which are innocuous in moderation . Basically , you are drinking expensive fizzy water that is dissolving your teeth ( it 's pretty acidic ) . If you drink a lot of it , you 'll probably notice symptoms of caffeine overdose before anything else . Several deaths have been blamed on Monster energy drinks and they tend to be smaller people and believed to be from caffeine overdose .

When you first choose a door , there is a 1 in 3 chance of picking the door with a prize behind it . * You are more likely to have picked a door with no prize . * You would , theoretically , expect to pick a door with no prize 2 out of 3 times . Then , a * * door with no prize * * is eliminated . But , since you 've * probably * picked the * * other * * door with no prize ( and they ca n't have eliminated your door ) - the * * * most likely * * * scenario is that you 've picked a door with no prize , a second door with no prize has been eliminated , and the * * door you can switch to has the prize * * .

Imagine that the prize is in door 1 ( this does n't really matter , all cases are equivalent ) . Now , make a table with the possibilities . Pick door 1 : * Do n't switch : * * Win * * * Switch ( to door 2 or 3 ): ~~Lose~~ Pick door 2 : * Do n't switch : ~~Lose~~ * Switch ( to door 1 ): * * Win * * Pick door 3 : * Do n't switch : ~~Lose~~ * Switch ( to door 1 ): * * Win * * So there you have it . Switching guarantees you win 2 out of 3 times .

One way is to actually play the game with somebody . Do it with playing cards for example ; say you have an ace and two 2 's , and the ace is the " prize . " Get a friend to play the game with you , in the following way : You pick a card . Your friend looks at it , and if it 's the ace , he arbitrarily picks one of the other two cards and shows it to you , and if it 's not the ace , he picks the one of the other two that is also not the ace and shows it to you . Then he asks you if you 'd like to switch ( from the one you originally picked to the remaining card that you have n't seen yet ) . You say " yes " every time and you will win 2/3 of the time . It may be even more clear if you switch roles so your friend is picking and you are showing .
chatgpt_answers: Sure! The Monty Hall Problem is a famous probability puzzle named after the host of a game show called "Let's Make a Deal." Here's how it works: Imagine that you're a contestant on the game show, and Monty Hall shows you three doors. He tells you that behind one of the doors is a prize, like a new car or a trip to a fancy vacation spot. Behind the other two doors are nothing, just some old junk. You get to choose one of the doors, and you don't know which door has the prize. Let's say that you choose Door #1. Monty Hall then opens Door #3, and shows you that there is no prize behind it. He then asks you if you want to stick with your original choice of Door #1, or switch to Door #2. What should you do? Stick with Door #1 or switch to Door #2? It might seem like it doesn't matter, since there are only two doors left and you have a 50-50 chance of getting the prize no matter which door you choose. But actually, it's better to switch to Door #2! Here's why: Before Monty Hall opened Door #3, you had a 1 in 3 chance of winning the prize, no matter which door you chose. That's because there were three doors and only one had the prize. So if you chose Door #1, you had a 1 in 3 chance of winning. But when Monty Hall opened Door #3 and showed you that it was empty, he changed the odds. Now, there are only two doors left, but only one of them has the prize. That means that if you switch to Door #2, you now have a 2 in 3 chance of winning the prize, because there's a 2 in 3 chance that the prize is behind Door #2. So by switching doors, you actually increase your chances of winning the prize! It might seem counterintuitive, but that's the magic of the Monty Hall Problem.

question: the difference between Baroque , Classical and Romantic music How do I differentiate music from each period just by listening to it ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Here 's my layman 's opinion : Baroque is characterized by extremely regular beats and a regularity to the music throughout the piece . The key does n't change ( I 'm sorry , I ca n't explain key to a 5 year old ! ) [ Here 's an image ] ( URL_1 ) of baroque music . Note that all the notes look the same ! Each part of the music sounds recognizably like another part of the music in the same work . Classical music is more sophisticated than baroque , but not too crazily different . [ If you look at the sheet music ] ( URL_2 ) you 'll see that there 's more of a variation on the piece . Compare two measures ( the notes between the long up and down lines ) and they may look very different . Romantic music has its shit all over the place . From one moment to the next , the work may sound very different . The chords are not as traditional . Often , the range of the piece can be large . If you hear cannons in the music , it 's likely romantic ;) Here 's what I think of as typical romantic era [ sheet music . ] ( URL_0 )

It 's generally a slow evolution from showing off your expertise , to conveying emotions through music . Baroque was named for the idea of " broken " chords - this is why you do n't hear block chords in Baroque music . They would arpeggiate everything . Another distinct thing to listen for in Baroque music is ornaments - things like trills , turns , mordents , anything added into the music . As players got better , they showed their unique skills by adding these in to show their expertise of the music and the instrument . Harpsichordists HAD to use these things because their notes did n't sustain , and if the note had to be heard for 2 beats , they did what they had to to make it happen . Classical is harder to define , but I really do think of it as the bridge between Baroque and Romantic . It still had elements of the Baroque ( ornaments , some broken chords ) but started to shift into more expressive and lyrical things . Romantic was when things started getting a little fruity . When you can hear nuances like pauses and LOTS of dynamic changes , taking time with the music and such , you 'll know you 're listening to a Romantic piece .

I always use the instrumentation as a guide , for example , there were no trumpets or low brass in baroque and there is very little harpsichord in romantic music . Think of it as an evolution of musical styles as well as the orchestra itself . If you listen to some JS Bach or Susato then listen to Debussy you will notice an obvious difference in the music but if you listen to the instruments making the music there are differences . The brass is much bolder as engineering techniques have improved the amount of chords used is larger and there are many more percussion instruments too . Apologies for it being a bit brief ... on mobile .

e term baroque refers to a style of art that developed in Europe around the 17th century. In addition to painting, sculpture, architecture, literature and theater were also used for this type of expression. The main characteristics are the use of contrasts, symmetry and balance, as well as the presence of a single focus point. In the case of music, baroque has two parts: the first one is from about 1600 until the mid-17th century and the second one ends with the beginning of the classical era. It was during these times that composers such as Claudio Monteverdi (1567‚Äì1643), Johann Sebastian Bach (1685‚Äì1750) or George Frideric Handel (1685‚Äì1759) emerged; they contributed greatly to the development of European musical genres such as opera, cantata, sonata or concerto grosso among others.
Classical music is a style of music that developed in Europe starting in the late 18th century and lasting through the early 19th century. This period saw many changes in how people listened to and performed music, including more organized rehearsals and concerts. Composers also began writing longer pieces that were intended for solo instruments or small groups rather than large orchestras.
Romanticism is an artistic movement that began in Europe at the end of the 18th century and lasted until the middle of the 19th century. Its most important feature was its emphasis on emotion, feelings, and individuality over reason or rationality. Some characteristics associated with romanticism include:
A focus on nature and landscape paintings A preference for simple, everyday scenes over grandiose ones An interest in telling stories through art An appreciation for beauty An idealization

### What is a Stop Loss?
A **stop loss** is an order placed with your broker to sell a security when it reaches a specific price. The purpose of a stop-loss order is to limit an investor‚Äôs loss on a security that has declined in value.

---

### Executing a Stop Loss at the Purchase Price

If you buy a stock at $50 and set a stop loss at the **purchase price** (i.e., $50), then:

- Your stop loss will trigger if the stock price falls to **$50**.
- Once triggered, the stop loss becomes a **market order** and your shares will be sold at the next available market price (which may be slightly below $50 due to market volatility).

However, setting a stop loss exactly at the purchase price is not very effective for several reasons:

---

   - Prices often fluctuate rapidly. If you set a stop at $50, the price could drop to or below $50 quickly, resulting in a **limitation of loss** ‚Äî you might even lose more than the initial cost if the stock gaps down overnight or during volatile news events.

In the U.S., the standard settlement cycle for equities is **T+2**, meaning that a trade settled on Day 1 will settle on Day 3 (two business days after the trade date). However, in some cases, trades can be settled earlier ‚Äî this is referred to as **"settlement before T+2"**, or sometimes **"T+1"** or even **"T+0"** depending on the market and circumstances.

So, "settling before T+3" could mean:

- The transaction settles earlier than the usual T+3 (which would imply it's settled on Day 1 or Day 2).

### Clarifying Common Settlement Terms:
- **T+0**: Immediate settlement, usually only available for certain types of instruments like ETFs or options.
- **T+1**: Settlement occurs one business day after the trade date.
- **T+2**: Standard settlement in many U.S. markets.
- **T+3**: An extended settlement period, which might occur under specific conditions such as weekends, holidays, or in certain markets.

human_answers: I 'm going to assume you know what an equation is , basic math , and how equations work . A * solution * to an equation is a set of number that satisfy that equation . For example , we can look at the equation x^2 + y^2 = z^2 . If we pick x to be 3 , y to be 4 , and z to be 5 , then we have a solution since x^2 + y^2 = 3 ^ 2 + 4 ^ 2 = 9 + 16 = 25 = 5 ^ 2 = z^2 . Notice that our solution ‚Äî x = 3 , y = 4 , z = 5 ‚Äî is made of counting numbers ? We can consider a generalization of the above equation , x^n + y^n = z^n , where n is any counting number itself , and ask whether * that * equation has a solution made up entirely of counting numbers . For example , we could look at the equation x^3 + y^3 = z^3 , or x^10 + y^10 = z^10 . So we 've established that if n is 2 , then there are solutions made up only of counting numbers ( we used 3 , 4 , and 5 ) . Fermat 's Last Theorem says that if n is * bigger * than 2 then you ca n't find a solution made up only of counting numbers . If two of the numbers in your solution are counting numbers , then the third one wo n't be a counting number . The known proof of this theorem can not be explained like you 're five . It is highly technical and relies on extremely advanced mathematical techniques developed in the late 1900s .

question: Why are real-term bond yields systematically declining, and what does it mean for investors?
human_answers: On a longer time scale, the plot thickens:  It almost looks random.  A large drop in real rates in the mid-70s, a massive spike in the early 80s, followed by a slow multi-decade decline. The chaos doesn't seem to be due to interest rates.  They steadily climbed and steadily fell:  All that's left is inflation:  First, real rates should be expected to pay a moderate rate, so nominal rates will usually be higher than inflation. However, interest rates are very stable over long time periods while inflation is not.  Economists call this type of phenomenon "sticky pricing", where the price, interest rates in this case, do not change much despite the realities surrounding them. But the story is a little more complicated. In the early 1970s, Nixon had an election to win and tried to lessen the impacts of recession by increasing gov't spending, not raising taxes, and financing through the central bank, causing inflation.  The strategy failed, but he was reelected anyways.   This set the precedent for the hyperinflation of the 1970s that ended abruptly by Reagan at the beginning of his first term in the early 1980s.  Again, interest rates remained sticky, so real rates spiked. Now, the world is not growing, almost stagnating.  Demand for equity is somewhat above average, but because corporate income is decelerating, and the developed world's population is aging, demand for investment income is skyrocketing.   As demand rises, so does the price, which for an investor is a form of inverse of the interest rate. Future demand is probably best answered by forecasters, and the monetarist over and undertones still dominating the Federal Reserve show that they have finally learned after 100 years that inflation is best kept "low and stable":  But what happens if growth in the US suddenly spikes, inflation rises, and the Federal Reserve must sell all of the long term assets it has bet so heavily on quickly while interest rates rise?  Inflation may not be intended, but it is not impossible.
chatgpt_answers: There are several reasons why real-term bond yields may be declining. One possible reason is that the demand for bonds is increasing, which can push down yields. On the one hand, falling yields may lead to capital appreciation for bondholders, as the market value of existing bonds tends to rise when yields fall. As such, it's important for investors to consider the risks and potential returns of any investment and to diversify their portfolios appropriately.

There are a number of factors that can contribute to declining real-term bond yields. Some of the most common include:Low inflation: If inflation is low, the purchasing power of the money that investors receive from bond coupons and principal payments is likely to be maintained over time. As a result, investors may be willing to accept lower yields on bonds.Central bank policy: Central banks can influence bond yields through their monetary policy decisions. For example, if a central bank lowers interest rates or engages in quantitative easing (which involves buying large amounts of government bonds), it can put downward pressure on bond yields.Economic conditions: Bond yields may also decline in response to economic conditions such as slow growth, low levels of business activity, or high levels of uncertainty. In such cases, investors may be more risk-averse and willing to accept lower yields in exchange for the relative safety of fixed-income investments.Demographic factors: An aging population may also contribute to declining bond yields, as older investors tend to have a greater demand for fixed-income investments.For investors, declining bond yields can have both positive and negative implications. On the one hand, lower yields can make bonds more attractive as investments, as investors will receive a lower return but may still be able to preserve their capital. On the other hand, declining bond yields can also signal economic weakness or deflationary pressures, which may be negative for overall financial markets and the broader economy.

human_answers: There are two types of nuclear bomb . Fission bombs ( often called atomic bombs ) and fusion bombs ( often called hydrogen bombs ) . Atomic bombs rely on a process called nuclear fission . This means splitting a heavy atom ( such as plutonium or uranium ) into smaller atoms and releasing a great deal of energy in the process . Fusion bombs rely on fusing light atoms ( such as hydrogen ) into larger atoms , which also releases a great deal of energy . However , in order to get the light atoms to fuse together you have to raise the temperature very high . The best way to do this is by using a conventional fission bomb positioned around the hydrogen fuel . This compresses the hydrogen and heats it up , which ignites the fusion process . question: What was "Freedom Summer"?
human_answers: Freedom Summer (also known as the Mississippi Summer Project) was a campaign in the United States launched in June 1964 to attempt to register as many African American voters as possible in Mississippi , which had historically excluded most blacks from voting.The project also set up dozens of Freedom Schools, Freedom Houses, and community centers in small towns throughout Mississippi to aid the local black population.
chatgpt_answers: "Freedom Summer" was a campaign in the United States in 1964 to register African American voters in Mississippi. It was organized by civil rights organizations, including the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee (SNCC) and the Congress of Racial Equality (CORE), and was supported by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP).\n\nDuring the summer of 1964, hundreds of student volunteers from around the country, both black and white, traveled to Mississippi to work on voter registration and other civil rights issues. The campaign was met with violent resistance from segregationist whites, and several Freedom Summer activists were killed or went missing. Despite the challenges and dangers, the campaign was successful in increasing voter registration among African Americans in Mississippi and helped to pave the way for the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

This is often the case when the policyholder has taken out a mortgage to purchase the property and the lender has a lien on the property as collateral for the loan. question: - How did we verify that gravity has a speed ? Gravity apparently travels at or near the speed of light , but how do we know that ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: It was a theory that came out from general relativity . When people started to apply the new theory of general relativity on different mechanics to see if they could find a flaw it was discovered that the observed motions of Mercury were much closer to the calculations if you used the fact that gravity were limited to the speed of light . This was one of the first big observations that would help make general relativity accepted .

> Gravity apparently travels at or near the speed of light , but how do we know that ? The simple answer : from observation . We can measure gravitational effects as we see them , not before , not after . If " gravity " was slower or faster than light , we 'd see cosmic events - for example fast - spinning double star systems - before or after the gravitational effects are measurable . But that is not the fact , graviational effects show up just as the light reaches us . Interesting is that Newton , who had no " cosmic scale " observation that were precise enough , still assumed that Gravity would propagate instantly through space .

Everything we know about modern physics ( deriving from special relativity ) says no information can travel faster than light . If gravitational waves did travel faster than light , then we could conceivably build machines to transmit information faster than light . What about slower ? Well , general relativity tells us one thing but nobody * really * knew for sure until last year . When the LIGO detector ( actually made of two detectors ) detected the gravitational waves from the black hole merger , it 's possible to measure how fast the gravitational waves traveled due to the distance between the detectors .

question: Why does ~55 mph seem to be the sweet spot for car MPG efficiency ? Why is it that about 55 mph is the sweet spot for best MPG efficiency , given normal driving conditions ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Quick Answer : It is . Most vehicles will reach their final gear ( 4th , 5th , 6th , 7th or even 8th ) at around 55 mph . The vehicle has usually reached the maximum speed at the lowest rpm possible ( engine spins slower ) . Also air resistance increases the faster you go obviously so the engine does n't need to work as hard to overcome aerodynamic drag .

For many years in the US , 55 mph was the maximum allowed speed , and in many places , it is the still fastest you will see outside of a major highway . So when manufacturers design their cars , they are geared to reach to top gear at around 55 mph , and fuel economy will fall of quickly after that .
The most efficient speed is the lowest possible speed in the highest possible gear . This has been confirmed by independent studies .

The sweet spot for a car's fuel efficiency is the speed at which the car uses the least amount of fuel to travel a certain distance. This is because the amount of fuel a car uses depends on several factors, including the speed at which it is driven, the weight of the car, the drag on the car (caused by wind resistance and other factors), and the efficiency of the engine.

At lower speeds, a car's engine is not working as hard, so it uses less fuel. However, as the car's speed increases, so does the drag on the car, which means the engine has to work harder to overcome the resistance and maintain the higher speed. This leads to an increase in fuel consumption.

At very high speeds, the drag on the car becomes even greater, which means the engine has to work even harder and use even more fuel.

So, there is a sweet spot for fuel efficiency where the engine is working hard enough to maintain a reasonable speed, but not so hard that it is using a lot of fuel. For most cars, this sweet spot is around 55 mph. At this speed, the car is able to maintain a good balance between fuel efficiency and speed.

question: What is PayPal , and why does it need to exist ? Why ca n't you just enter your debit / credit card info ? Seems pointless and excessive , but probably because I do n't understand how it works . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Paypal is essentially an organized and trusted middleman between two parties . Back when eBay started out , believe it or not , it ran on the honor system and did okay , but not great for the most part . You won an auction then actually sent the seller a money order . S / he would get it and send you your item . Of course you could make a fake account sell something that never existed and wait for your money order and then disappear . So Elon Musk , ( the guy you hear about in the news a lot with Tesla cars and South African scientist / businessman ) creates PayPal as a secure way of moving money between parties on the internet . Buyers stopped getting ripped off because they offer buyer protection and eBay becomes secure . Why eBay did n't think of this at first is anyone 's guess . eBay did make their own payment system but by then PayPal became so popular eBay bought Paypal and made Mr. Musk a billionaire . * * What does paypal do ? * * It essentially acts as not only a middleman , but a virtual bank ( but not a real bank at all ) with real money linked to your real bank account . You can put money in , and take money out . You can pay with a credit card , you can pay with the funds in the account , you can pay with checks . It 's effective as a third party between buyers who are not businesses . Say you , Edigi135 wants to sell me your cats and I want to pay with my credit card . Since you do n't have a credit card machine , we use Paypal and it handles the transaction for us . Since Paypal is a trusted name , we both think there is no chance of either of us ripping each other off or me running away with your cats . I pay with my credit card , you see that the paypal transaction goes through then you send me the cats . Easy . * * PS**-There are some problems with Paypal and I 'm just going to use this space to devote some text to it . The inherent problem with Paypal is that it favors the buyer far far far more than the seller in terms of protection . There are thousands of scams , mostly on craigslist . If you sell an item these scammers will pretend to overpay you for an item . Sounds good so far . They claim to live far away so they want the item shipped . So the seller ships it and then the scammer says " wait I never got it / it 's broken / this is n't what you said it was " . They contact paypal and paypal refunds their money because they always side with the buyer . So not only are they getting their money back , you lost your item . On top of that , if you withdrew the money and refuse to refund it you could damage your credit ! That 's three strikes against you for one transaction . eBay does n't have this issue because they offer seller protection . Outside of eBay , you are on your own . And as another user pointed out below , PayPal monitors accounts more harshly than banks . If I sell some stuff for $ 3000 then PayPal might go whoa ! you have n't used your account in 5 years , hold on buddy while we check this out and hold your account for review . It 's frustrating at times and they will often call you to confirm transactions . It gets cumbersome when really a money order becomes more attractive in that regard . Another thing that holds PayPal back is that you can not withdraw money quickly from the virtual account . For some reason it takes a whole five business days unlike a real bank . This makes transactions slow and tedious if you need money right away . I have sent money owned to friends via PayPal and they are n't particularly happy because now that money is stuck in their system for over a week . As of now , PayPal has become a tool for eBay and is n't used so much out of that context . You might see some cheaper and startup online vendors use it to take credit cards and that 's about the extent of its usefulness today .

Something else that makes Paypal attractive ( to sellers ) is the fee structure of PayPal vs. credit cards . Visa and other card companies charge 3 - 4 % of each transaction as a fee , but more importantly in this context , they have a minimum transaction fee of like a dollar- meaning that it is not cost effective for a seller to accept a $ 5 purchase via credit card payment . This is where PayPal offers an advantage vs. a credit card . Paypal charges a small percentage transaction fee as well , but no minimum fee means they 're fine getting $ 0.05 on a one dollar transaction- making it cost effective for a seller on eBay , etsy , wherever to offer you something for $ 2.00 where it was n't before .

question: Cognitive Dissonance There was a post in SRD that has something to do with cognitive dissonance , and I read the wiki but it 's still really confusing . Thread : URL_0 Please explain like I'm five.
human_answers: What you linked is not a proper use of the term . It gets misused a lot . Cognitive dissonance is an uncomfortable feeling you experience when two of your beliefs are in conflict . It often happens when deeply held beliefs are challenged . Let 's say you were raised to believe that people who drink alcohol are bad people . You go away to college and become best friends with your roommate . You now believe these two things . 1 . People who drink alcohol are bad people . 2 . My roommate is a good person . A couple months later , you see your roommate drinking beer at a party . This puts your two beliefs into conflict with each other . Both ca n't be true at the same time , so you have to reconcile them somehow . There are several ways people deal with this problem . Some people deal with the problem by refusing to deal with the problem . They do n't think about it . This is not the most healthy option , but it 's what some people do . If you ca n't or wo n't avoid thinking about the conflicting beliefs , you have to change one of your beliefs . One option is to accept that what you were taught growing up is wrong , and drinking alcohol does not make you a bad person . Another option is to change your opinion of your roommate . Your roommate drinks alcohol , and is therefore bad . The third option is to deny you saw your roommate drinking . Nope , never happened . Of those options , some are more sensible than others , but they are all ways people might actually handle the situation .

People strive for consistency between their attitudes . When two or more attitudes contradict each other , for exaple " I smoke " and " smoking is dangerous " , you will experience an uncomfortable feeling of anxiety , called cognitive dissonance . This discomfort will motivate you to reduce the dissonance . The theory states that to reduce the dissonance , and maintain consistency between attitudes , people will either change their attitudes , or add new ones . For example either by quitting smoking , or by adding the attitude " it 's not as dangerous to smoke as they claim " .

It 's when you hold two opposing ideas in your head at the same time , or when you have new information that contradicts a deeply held belief . I suppose the easiest example is someone who has grown up religious most of their life , say as a creationist ( someone who believes god created everything in front of them and that natural processes were n't involved ) . What happens when this person goes to biology and starts learning about evolution ? The idea of evolution is totally absent of any kind of intelligence guiding the process . Looking at it very simply , it seems like random chance after random chance that led to where we are today . This understandably goes against what they 've been told all their life , especially when it comes to the idea of god having a " plan . " Taken on its face , there 's obviously no plan when it comes to evolution . No intelligence . Completely natural and without guidance . I think that 's why those who do n't believe in evolution are some of the most vehement in their position even if they may not have much of a leg to stand on . Their attacks on evolution are tied into their very identity , so it 's understandable why they 're passionate about their position .
chatgpt_answers: Cognitive dissonance is a term that refers to the mental discomfort or tension that a person experiences when they hold two conflicting beliefs or values at the same time. For example, if a person values honesty but finds themselves lying to someone, they may experience cognitive dissonance because these two beliefs or values are in conflict with each other. To understand this concept more easily, imagine that you really love chocolate ice cream, but you also know that eating too much ice cream is not good for your health. When you have a craving for ice cream, you may experience cognitive dissonance because you want to enjoy the ice cream but you also know that it's not good for you. Cognitive dissonance can be uncomfortable and people may try to reduce this discomfort by changing their beliefs or behavior. For example, if a person who values honesty finds themselves lying, they may try to make up for their lie by being extra honest in the future. Alternatively, they may try to justify their lie by convincing themselves that it was necessary or that the person they lied to deserved it. Cognitive dissonance is a common and natural part of human psychology and can be a powerful force in shaping our beliefs and behaviors. It's important to be aware of cognitive dissonance and to try to reduce it by aligning our beliefs and actions with our values and goals.

human_answers: In simple terms - whenever something is moving in a circle , it has centripetal force . This force is perpendicular to the center of the circle . ( Example : think about spinning around while holding onto a shopping bag at arm 's length . When you let go of that bag , it will travel in a straight line away from you - perpendicular to your core , the center of its spinny circle . ) In space , when something is above the earth , there is gravity pulling it back down towards earth . So what happens when the centripetal force is equal to gravity ? The answer is geosynchronous orbit ! The object is falling in towards the earth at the same rate that it 's trying to shoot off perpendicular to the earth . The result is that it follows a curved path that keeps it at the same height , as the two forces cancel ! Fun note 1 : one big benefit of geosynchronous orbits is that they 're also geostationary - this means that a satellite is in the same place all the time in relation to the earth , so it 's easy to figure out where to point satellite dishes . Fun note 2 : over time , geosynchronous orbits slowly decay , so eventually those satellites will come crashing back down to earth ... cover your heads !

A dormant company is one that:

- Has no income,

In the UK, even a dormant company must comply with certain legal and tax requirements:

#### A) **Company Registration and Filing Requirements**
- You must register the company at Companies House.
- You are required to file annual accounts and confirmation statements every year, even if the company is dormant.

### 1. **Avoiding Capital Gains Taxes on Long-Term Investments**
This interpretation refers to strategies aimed at **minimizing or avoiding the tax liability** that comes with selling an asset (like stocks, real estate, etc.) that has appreciated in value.

#### What is a Capital Gain?
A **capital gain** occurs when you sell an investment for more than its original purchase price. If held for more than one year, it‚Äôs considered a **long-term capital gain**, and generally taxed at a lower rate than short-term gains (which are taxed as ordinary income).

#### Strategies to Avoid or Minimize Capital Gains Taxes:
- **Hold investments for more than one year**: This qualifies them as long-term gains, which are typically taxed at a lower rate.
- **Use tax-deferred accounts** like IRAs or 401(k)s: Earnings grow without immediate taxation.
- **Tax-loss harvesting**: Sell losing positions to offset capital gains from other investments.
- **Charitable contributions of appreciated assets**: Donate stock or property directly to charity; no capital gains tax due.
- **Offset gains with losses** through strategic trading.
- **Use municipal bonds**: Often exempt from federal and state taxes.
- **Consider Roth IRA conversions**: Depending on your situation, converting traditional IRA funds to a Roth IRA can reduce future tax exposure.
- **Use Section 1202 (for certain startups)**: Allows up to $10 million in exclusion from capital gains tax.

> ‚ö†Ô∏è Note: Completely avoiding capital gains tax is difficult and often not

question: Please explain what is "Lisp (programming language)"
human_answers:
Lisp (historically LISP) is a family of programming languages with a long history and a distinctive, fully parenthesized prefix notation.
Originally specified in 1960, Lisp is the second-oldest high-level programming language still in common use, after Fortran. Lisp has changed since its early days, and many dialects have existed over its history. Today, the best-known general-purpose Lisp dialects are Common Lisp, Scheme, Racket and Clojure.
Lisp was originally created as a practical mathematical notation for computer programs, influenced by (though not originally derived from) the notation of Alonzo Church's lambda calculus. It quickly became a favored programming language for artificial intelligence (AI) research.[10] As one of the earliest programming languages, Lisp pioneered many ideas in computer science, including tree data structures, automatic storage management, dynamic typing, conditionals, higher-order functions, recursion, the self-hosting compiler,[11] and the read‚Äìeval‚Äìprint loop.[12]
The name LISP derives from "LISt Processor".[13] Linked lists are one of Lisp's major data structures, and Lisp source code is made of lists. Thus, Lisp programs can manipulate source code as a data structure, giving rise to the macro systems that allow programmers to create new syntax or new domain-specific languages embedded in Lisp.
The interchangeability of code and data gives Lisp its instantly recognizable syntax. All program code is written as s-expressions, or parenthesized lists. A function call or syntactic form is written as a list with the function or operator's name first, and the arguments following; for instance, a function f that takes three arguments would be called as (f arg1 arg2 arg3).

If you ask for the time and I say my phone is dead , years ago that would have made no sense . As far as writing one - liner jokes go , see an object that you find peculiar , then just think about it , think about what relates to it , think of what is obscure about it and then put it one sentence . After you write 500 of those , spanning many different topics , pick out the 50 best ones or pair the jokes that share a common topic and reword them ( if possible ) so they fit more like a puzzle piece . When he says 3 one - liners in a row that are all on the same topic , it 's likely that he wrote them at 3 different times , maybe years apart . question: Why can every bus on Schiphol airport be electric , but not all buses in general ? I was recently on Schiphol and I noticed this . Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: Electric vehicles are more practical when they only have to travel short distances and have easy access to charging facilities . A bus that makes the same 1 mile loop every day fits that description . A bus that travels a couple hundred miles a day , not as much .

The problem with most electric vehicles is that , unless they stay on charging rails , they have a pretty limited range ; they can only go a few dozen miles , up to a few hundred on the state of the art models , before needing to be plugged in or to swap out their battery . Airports are great for electric buses because , while they may drive around a lot , it 's all in a fairly small geographic space . They 're never far from a charging station , and can even install charging cables along their routes . Airports also serve the function of being the ambassadors to an entire region ; travelers often judge a city by the quality of its airport . Cities are thus willing to chose more expensive , more environmentally friendly options at the airport in order to make a good impression .

Electric buses require infrastructure . If they are the trolley type , they get their power from overhead wires . If they are electric vehicles , they need somewhere to plug in and recharge their batteries . Either way it 's easiest to roll out an electric bus program on a smaller scale - like an airport - because you either need to build a bunch of overhead wires , or a big depot with lots of charging stations for the whole fleet . There are larger scale electric bus operations in the world , though . Vancouver , British Columbia has overhead wires on most of the major roads for trolley style electric buses .

question: Is there a biological or social reason as to why there is always a line for the ladies restroom as compared to the mens ? Do women have smaller bladders or something ? Explain like I'm five.
human_answers: People tend to pee more often than they poop . Peeing takes less time than pooping , but takes more time for women as they need to go into a stall , sit down , pee , wipe , flush , and then proceed instead of just walking up to a urinal , unzipping , peeing , then rezipping . There 's less demand for toilets for men , so if someone 's taking a massive shit and taking forever , he 's not holding up people who want to pee . If there 's a women 's bathroom with 4 toilets and two people are taking a crap , you 've halved the throughput of the restroom for people who want to pee as well . Talk about a bottleneck !

It 's an architectural engineering problem . Men have the ability to urinate while standing in a normal , upright position . For women , it is more efficient and hygenic to urinate while seated on a toilet ( or , in some countries , squatting is the preferred method ) . Because a standing urinal takes up far less space than a toilet stall , given an equal amount of space , you will be able to provide more facilities per room for men to urinate ( urinals and toilet stalls combined ) than you can for women ( toilet stalls only ) , therefore the potential throughput ( number of people who can be accommodated in a given amount of time ) of a men 's restroom is greater than that of an equally - sized women 's restroom . So if you normalize for both sexes defecating in the same frequency and manner and frequency , and both sexes urinating with the same frequency but in a * different * manner , then the net benefit accrues to the men 's restroom because of the ability to fit a greater number of facilities for urination in the same - sized space .

It takes women longer to pee , that 's the main thing . They have to go into a stall , close the door , remove some clothing , sit down , pee , wipe , get up , open the door -- many extra seconds compared to a man . Even worse , you can fit only 2 stalls into a space that would hold 3 urinals .

question: How are bonds affected by the Federal Funds Rate?
human_answers: The federal funds rate is one of the risk-free short-term rates in the economy. We often think of fixed income securities as paying this rate plus some premia associated with risk. For a treasury security, we can think this way: (interest rate) = (fed funds rate) + (term premium) The term premium is a bit extra the bond pays because if you hold a long term bond, you are exposed to interest rate risk, which is the risk that rates will generally rise after you buy, making your bond worth less.  The relation is more complex if people have expectations of future rate moves, but this is the general idea.  Anyway, generally speaking, longer term bonds are exposed to more interest rate risk, so they pay more, on average. For a corporate bond, we think this way: (interest rate) = (fed funds rate) + (term premium) + (default premium) where the default premium is some extra that the bond must pay to compensate the holder for default risk, which is the risk that the bond defaults or loses value as the company's prospects fall.  You can see that corporate and government bonds are affected the same way (approximately, this is all hand-waving) by changes in the fed funds rate. Now, that all refers to the rates on new bonds.  After a bond is issued, its value falls if rates rise because new bonds are relatively more attractive.  Its value rises if rates on new bonds falls.  So if there is an unexpected rise in the fed funds rate and you are holding a bond, you will be sad, especially if it is a long term bond (doesn't matter if it's corporate or government).  Ask yourself, though, whether an increase in fed funds will be unexpected at this point.  If the increase was expected, it will already be priced in.  Are you more of an expert than the folks on wall-street at predicting interest rate changes?  If not, it might not make sense to make decisions based on your belief about where rates are going.  Just saying. Brick points out that treasuries are tax advantaged.  That is, you don't have to pay state income tax on them (but you do pay federal). If you live in a state where this is true, this may matter to you a little bit. They also pay unnaturally little because they are convenient for use as a cash substitute in transactions and margining ("convenience yield").  In general, treasuries just don't pay much.  Young folk like you tend to buy corporate bonds instead, so they can make money on the default and term premia.

For example, changes in economic conditions, inflation expectations, and the supply and demand for bonds can all impact bond yields independently of the Federal Funds Rate.

As long as you give an identical widget back to the person at the end of the month , they do n't care . Now you sell the widget . Currently , widgets cost $ 10 . So you gain $ 10 . But you still owe the person a widget . Now , suppose the price of widgets drops . At the end of the month , the day before you have to give the widget back , widgets only cost $ 6 . You spend $ 6 and buy the widget . You give the widget back to the person . You spent $ 1 ( widget rental ) and $ 6 ( buy a new widget ) , but you gained $ 10 ( widget sale ) . So on the balance , you are $ 3 richer . But only because the cost of widgets went down . Suppose the cost of widgets went from $ 10 to $ 12 . You had to spend $ 1 ( widget rental feel ) and $ 12 ( buy a new widget ) , but only made $ 10 . You now have $ 3 less than when you started ! This is why short - selling is dangerous . You have to be absolutely sure the price of widgets will go down , and you have to know exactly when . If you get either of these things wrong , you lose money . Maybe a lot of money , if you bought a lot of widgets or if widgets are very expensive .

### Here's how it works:

- The difference between the price they sold it for and the lower price they bought it back for is their **profit**.

---

### Simple example:
You think a toy will cost $10 tomorrow, but today it costs $15.  
So you borrow the toy, sell it for $15, wait until tomorrow when it‚Äôs only worth $10, then buy it back for $10 and return it to the lender.  
You made $5 profit ‚Äî that‚Äôs how short selling works!

think you have to be more specific than just "short selling". Short selling has two meanings - either one of them or both could apply. First, it can mean buying on margin, where you borrow money from your broker in order to buy stocks that are expected to rise in price quickly and then sell them off at a profit, paying back the money borrowed from your broker with interest as the proceeds from the sale come in. This is not considered short selling per se because no actual shares are sold ; rather they are used as collateral for borrowing the funds needed to purchase the shares in the first place. Second, it means betting against someone else's belief that an asset will rise by borrowing that same asset at one price and selling it immediately at another higher price after which time you repay what was borrowed plus some fees while keeping any difference between those two prices as profits for yourself ( this doesn't involve selling anything outright though ).
1. In finance, ‚Äúselling short‚Äù refers to borrowing stock certificates from a brokerage firm and selling them in anticipation of repaying those loans when the stock drops below its current price.
2. A short position is created when an investor borrows securities such as stocks or bonds and sells them expecting the price will fall so they can buy them back later at a lower cost.
3. Selling short occurs when investors use borrowed cash to make trades believing prices will go down before returning the borrowed securities.
4. Investors take advantage of selling shorts by anticipating future events that will cause declines in demand leading to falling share values allowing them time enough before repayment dates arrive without having too much risk involved themselves
5. The goal behind taking out short positions is usually profiting off losses incurred due others who hold onto their investments

Okay, imagine you're playing a fun game of tag with your friends outside. Usually, everyone tries their best to avoid bumping or grabbing each other because that's not nice and can hurt feelings.

But sometimes, when someone really goes too far‚Äîmaybe they push another kid down instead of just playfully tackling‚Äîthey get sent to the side for a time-out (that's like the penalty box). This helps so the player who got pushed isn't upset and can still have fun later on.

Now, thinking about hockey: It's played by big people wearing special equipment (like helmets and pads) so they don't always break bones if they bump into each other. But there's one rule exception ‚Äì fighting is allowed! Hockey players sometimes decide to argue and use fists instead of sticks to solve things quickly.

So, why does that happen? It could be because:
1.  **Showing Strength:** Players want to show others they aren't afraid of anyone and will protect their team members.
2.  **Stopping Arguments:** A quick punch might stop an argument right away between two opposing teams.
3.  **Making Moves Disappear Faster:** Some think getting rid of a tough opponent fast means more playing time overall (though this idea is often debated).
4.  **Tradition & Excitement:** Hockey has been around for a long time, and fans love the excitement, even though nobody wants real injury or violence!

It's like the only time-out action in hockey becomes punching instead of being stopped.
